         [57]
        </a>
       </sup>
       while ongoing validation is provided as a side effect of the operation of the
       <a href="/wiki/Global_Positioning_System" title="Global Positioning System">
        Global Positioning System
       </a>
       (GPS).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58">
        <a href="#cite_note-58">
         [58]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Tests in stronger gravitational fields are provided by the observation of
       <a href="/wiki/Binary_pulsar" title="Binary pulsar">
        binary pulsars
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59">
        <a href="#cite_note-59">
         [59]
        </a>
       </sup>
       All results are in agreement with general relativity.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60">
        <a href="#cite_note-60">
         [60]
        </a>
       </sup>
       However, at the current level of accuracy, these observations cannot distinguish between general relativity and other theories in which the equivalence principle is valid.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61">
        <a href="#cite_note-61">
         [61]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Light_deflection_and_gravitational_time_delay">
        Light deflection and gravitational time delay
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=General_relativity&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: Light deflection and gravitational time delay">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kepler_problem_in_general_relativity" title="Kepler problem in general relativity">
        Kepler problem in general relativity
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Gravitational_lens" title="Gravitational lens">
        Gravitational lens
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Shapiro_delay" title="Shapiro delay">
        Shapiro delay
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Light_deflection.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="352" data-file-width="300" height="199" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Light_deflection.png/170px-Light_deflection.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Light_deflection.png/255px-Light_deflection.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/c2/Light_deflection.png 2x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Light_deflection.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Deflection of light (sent out from the location shown in blue) near a compact body (shown in gray)
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       General relativity predicts that the path of light will follow the curvature of spacetime as it passes near a star. This effect was initially confirmed by observing the light of stars or distant quasars being deflected as it passes the
       <a href="/wiki/Sun" title="Sun">
        Sun
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62">
        <a href="#cite_note-62">
         [62]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       This and related predictions follow from the fact that light follows what is called a light-like or null geodesic—a generalization of the straight lines along which light travels in classical physics. Such geodesics are the generalization of the
       <a href="/wiki/Invariant_(mathematics)" title="Invariant (mathematics)">
        invariance
       </a>
       of lightspeed in special relativity.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63">
        <a href="#cite_note-63">
         [63]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As one examines suitable model spacetimes (either the exterior Schwarzschild solution or, for more than a single mass, the post-Newtonian expansion),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64">
        <a href="#cite_note-64">
         [64]
        </a>
       </sup>
       several effects of gravity on light propagation emerge. Although the bending of light can also be derived by extending the universality of free fall to light,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65">
        <a href="#cite_note-65">
         [65]
        </a>
       </sup>
       the angle of deflection resulting from such calculations is only half the value given by general relativity.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66">
        <a href="#cite_note-66">
         [66]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Closely related to light deflection is the gravitational time delay (or Shapiro delay), the phenomenon that light signals take longer to move through a gravitational field than they would in the absence of that field. There have been numerous successful tests of this prediction.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67">
        <a href="#cite_note-67">
         [67]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In the
       <a href="/wiki/Parameterized_post-Newtonian_formalism" title="Parameterized post-Newtonian formalism">
        parameterized post-Newtonian formalism
       </a>
       (PPN), measurements of both the deflection of light and the gravitational time delay determine a parameter called γ, which encodes the influence of gravity on the geometry of space.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68">
        <a href="#cite_note-68">
         [68]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div style="clear:both;">
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Gravitational_waves">
        Gravitational waves
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=General_relativity&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: Gravitational waves">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Gravitational_wave" title="Gravitational wave">
        Gravitational wave
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gravwav.gif">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="250" data-file-width="250" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Gravwav.gif/220px-Gravwav.gif" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/5c/Gravwav.gif 1.5x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Gravwav.gif" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Ring of test particles deformed by a passing (linearized, amplified for better visibility) gravitational wave
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Predicted in 1916
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69">
        <a href="#cite_note-69">
         [69]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70">
        <a href="#cite_note-70">
         [70]
        </a>
       </sup>
       by Albert Einstein, there are gravitational waves: ripples in the metric of spacetime that propagate at the speed of light. These are one of several analogies between weak-field gravity and electromagnetism in that, they are analogous to
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Electromagnetic_wave" title="Electromagnetic wave">
        electromagnetic waves
       </a>
       . On February 11, 2016, the Advanced LIGO team announced that they had
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gravitational_wave_observation" title="Gravitational wave observation">
        directly detected gravitational waves
       </a>
       from a
       <a href="/wiki/Binary_black_hole" title="Binary black hole">
        pair
       </a>
       of black holes
       <a href="/wiki/Stellar_collision" title="Stellar collision">
        merging
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Discovery_2016_71-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Discovery_2016-71">
         [71]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Abbot_72-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Abbot-72">
         [72]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NSF_73-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-NSF-73">
         [73]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The simplest type of such a wave can be visualized by its action on a ring of freely floating particles. A sine wave propagating through such a ring towards the reader distorts the ring in a characteristic, rhythmic fashion (animated image to the right).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74">
        <a href="#cite_note-74">
         [74]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Since Einstein's equations are
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Non-linear" title="Non-linear">
        non-linear
       </a>
       , arbitrarily strong gravitational waves do not obey
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Linear_superposition" title="Linear superposition">
        linear superposition
       </a>
       , making their description difficult. However, for weak fields, a linear approximation can be made. Such linearized gravitational waves are sufficiently accurate to describe the exceedingly weak waves that are expected to arrive here on Earth from far-off cosmic events, which typically result in relative distances increasing and decreasing by
       <span class="mwe-math-element">
        <span class="mwe-math-mathml-inline mwe-math-mathml-a11y" style="display: none;">
         <math alttext="{\displaystyle 10^{-21}}" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML">
          <semantics>
           <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
            <mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0">
             <msup>
              <mn>
               10
              </mn>
              <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
               <mo>
                −
                <!-- − -->
               </mo>
               <mn>
                21
               </mn>
              </mrow>
             </msup>
            </mstyle>
           </mrow>
           <annotation encoding="application/x-tex">
            {\displaystyle 10^{-21}}
           </annotation>
          </semantics>
         </math>
        </span>
        <img alt="10^{-21}" aria-hidden="true" class="mwe-math-fallback-image-inline" src="https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/6897cc272146f9756290c0ed5875bc68e49b3077" style="vertical-align: -0.338ex; width:5.48ex; height:2.676ex;"/>
       </span>
       or less. Data analysis methods routinely make use of the fact that these linearized waves can be
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fourier_decomposition" title="Fourier decomposition">
        Fourier decomposed
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75">
        <a href="#cite_note-75">
         [75]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Some exact solutions describe gravitational waves without any approximation, e.g., a wave train traveling through empty space
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-76">
        <a href="#cite_note-76">
         [76]
        </a>
       </sup>
       or
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gowdy_universe" title="Gowdy universe">
        Gowdy universes
       </a>
       , varieties of an expanding cosmos filled with gravitational waves.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77">
        <a href="#cite_note-77">
         [77]
        </a>
       </sup>
       But for gravitational waves produced in astrophysically relevant situations, such as the merger of two black holes, numerical methods are presently the only way to construct appropriate models.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78">
        <a href="#cite_note-78">
         [78]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Orbital_effects_and_the_relativity_of_direction">
        Orbital effects and the relativity of direction
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=General_relativity&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: Orbital effects and the relativity of direction">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kepler_problem_in_general_relativity" title="Kepler problem in general relativity">
        Kepler problem in general relativity
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       General relativity differs from classical mechanics in a number of predictions concerning orbiting bodies. It predicts an overall rotation (
       <a href="/wiki/Precession" title="Precession">
        precession
       </a>
       ) of planetary orbits, as well as orbital decay caused by the emission of gravitational waves and effects related to the relativity of direction.
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Precession_of_apsides">
        Precession of apsides
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=General_relativity&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: Precession of apsides">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Relativistic_precession.svg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="390" data-file-width="420" height="204" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Relativistic_precession.svg/220px-Relativistic_precession.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Relativistic_precession.svg/330px-Relativistic_precession.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Relativistic_precession.svg/440px-Relativistic_precession.svg.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Relativistic_precession.svg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Newtonian (red) vs. Einsteinian orbit (blue) of a lone planet orbiting a star
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       In general relativity, the
       <a href="/wiki/Apsis" title="Apsis">
        apsides
       </a>
       of any orbit (the point of the orbiting body's closest approach to the system's
       <a href="/wiki/Center_of_mass" title="Center of mass">
        center of mass
       </a>
       ) will precess—the orbit is not an
       <a href="/wiki/Ellipse" title="Ellipse">
        ellipse
       </a>
       , but akin to an ellipse that rotates on its focus, resulting in a
       <a href="/wiki/Rose_(mathematics)" title="Rose (mathematics)">
        rose curve
       </a>
       -like shape (see image). Einstein first derived this result by using an approximate metric representing the Newtonian limit and treating the orbiting body as a
       <a href="/wiki/Test_particle" title="Test particle">
        test particle
       </a>
       . For him, the fact that his theory gave a straightforward explanation of Mercury's anomalous perihelion shift, discovered earlier by
       <a href="/wiki/Urbain_Le_Verrier" title="Urbain Le Verrier">
        Urbain Le Verrier
       </a>
       in 1859, was important evidence that he had at last identified the correct form of the gravitational field equations.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79">
        <a href="#cite_note-79">
         [79]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The effect can also be derived by using either the exact Schwarzschild metric (describing spacetime around a spherical mass)
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80">
        <a href="#cite_note-80">
         [80]
        </a>
       </sup>
       or the much more general
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Post-Newtonian_formalism" title="Post-Newtonian formalism">
        post-Newtonian formalism
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81">
        <a href="#cite_note-81">
         [81]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It is due to the influence of gravity on the geometry of space and to the contribution of
       <a href="/wiki/Self-energy" title="Self-energy">
        self-energy
       </a>
       to a body's gravity (encoded in the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nonlinearity" title="Nonlinearity">
        nonlinearity
       </a>
       of Einstein's equations).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82">
        <a href="#cite_note-82">
         [82]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Relativistic precession has been observed for all planets that allow for accurate precession measurements (Mercury, Venus, and Earth),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83">
        <a href="#cite_note-83">
         [83]
        </a>
       </sup>
       as well as in binary pulsar systems, where it is larger by five
       <a href="/wiki/Order_of_magnitude" title="Order of magnitude">
        orders of magnitude
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84">
        <a href="#cite_note-84">
         [84]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In general relativity the perihelion shift σ, expressed in radians per revolution, is approximately given by:
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85">
        <a href="#cite_note-85">
         [85]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <dl>
       <dd>
        <span class="mwe-math-element">
         <span class="mwe-math-mathml-inline mwe-math-mathml-a11y" style="display: none;">
          <math alttext="{\displaystyle \sigma ={\frac {24\pi ^{3}L^{2}}{T^{2}c^{2}(1-e^{2})}}\ ,}" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML">
           <semantics>
            <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
             <mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0">
              <mi>
               σ
               <!-- σ -->
              </mi>
              <mo>
               =
              </mo>
              <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
               <mfrac>
                <mrow>
                 <mn>
                  24
                 </mn>
                 <msup>
                  <mi>
                   π
                   <!-- π -->
                  </mi>
                  <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
                   <mn>
                    3
                   </mn>
                  </mrow>
                 </msup>
                 <msup>
                  <mi>
                   L
                  </mi>
                  <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
                   <mn>
                    2
                   </mn>
                  </mrow>
                 </msup>
                </mrow>
                <mrow>
                 <msup>
                  <mi>
                   T
                  </mi>
                  <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
                   <mn>
                    2
                   </mn>
                  </mrow>
                 </msup>
                 <msup>
                  <mi>
                   c
                  </mi>
                  <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
                   <mn>
                    2
                   </mn>
                  </mrow>
                 </msup>
                 <mo stretchy="false">
                  (
                 </mo>
                 <mn>
                  1
                 </mn>
                 <mo>
                  −
                  <!-- − -->
                 </mo>
                 <msup>
                  <mi>
                   e
                  </mi>
                  <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
                   <mn>
                    2
                   </mn>
                  </mrow>
                 </msup>
                 <mo stretchy="false">
                  )
                 </mo>
                </mrow>
               </mfrac>
              </mrow>
              <mtext>
              </mtext>
              <mo>
               ,
              </mo>
             </mstyle>
            </mrow>
            <annotation encoding="application/x-tex">
             {\displaystyle \sigma ={\frac {24\pi ^{3}L^{2}}{T^{2}c^{2}(1-e^{2})}}\ ,}
            </annotation>
           </semantics>
          </math>
         </span>
         <img alt="{\displaystyle \sigma ={\frac {24\pi ^{3}L^{2}}{T^{2}c^{2}(1-e^{2})}}\ ,}" aria-hidden="true" class="mwe-math-fallback-image-inline" src="https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/e58b27c973a8dcd18661d17dbd71493077b077ce" style="vertical-align: -2.671ex; width:19.277ex; height:6.509ex;"/>
        </span>
       </dd>
      </dl>
      <p>
       where:
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <span class="mwe-math-element">
         <span class="mwe-math-mathml-inline mwe-math-mathml-a11y" style="display: none;">
          <math alttext="{\displaystyle L}" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML">
           <semantics>
            <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
             <mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0">
              <mi>
               L
              </mi>
             </mstyle>
            </mrow>
            <annotation encoding="application/x-tex">
             {\displaystyle L}
            </annotation>
           </semantics>
          </math>
         </span>
         <img alt="L" aria-hidden="true" class="mwe-math-fallback-image-inline" src="https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/103168b86f781fe6e9a4a87b8ea1cebe0ad4ede8" style="vertical-align: -0.338ex; width:1.583ex; height:2.176ex;"/>
        </span>
        is the
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Semi-major_axis" title="Semi-major axis">
         semi-major axis
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="mwe-math-element">
         <span class="mwe-math-mathml-inline mwe-math-mathml-a11y" style="display: none;">
          <math alttext="{\displaystyle T}" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML">
           <semantics>
            <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
             <mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0">
              <mi>
               T
              </mi>
             </mstyle>
            </mrow>
            <annotation encoding="application/x-tex">
             {\displaystyle T}
            </annotation>
           </semantics>
          </math>
         </span>
         <img alt="T" aria-hidden="true" class="mwe-math-fallback-image-inline" src="https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/ec7200acd984a1d3a3d7dc455e262fbe54f7f6e0" style="vertical-align: -0.338ex; width:1.636ex; height:2.176ex;"/>
        </span>
        is the
        <a href="/wiki/Orbital_period" title="Orbital period">
         orbital period
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="mwe-math-element">
         <span class="mwe-math-mathml-inline mwe-math-mathml-a11y" style="display: none;">
          <math alttext="{\displaystyle c}" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML">
           <semantics>
            <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
             <mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0">
              <mi>
               c
              </mi>
             </mstyle>
            </mrow>
            <annotation encoding="application/x-tex">
             {\displaystyle c}
            </annotation>
           </semantics>
          </math>
         </span>
         <img alt="c" aria-hidden="true" class="mwe-math-fallback-image-inline" src="https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/86a67b81c2de995bd608d5b2df50cd8cd7d92455" style="vertical-align: -0.338ex; width:1.007ex; height:1.676ex;"/>
        </span>
        is the speed of light
       </li>
       <li>
        <span class="mwe-math-element">
         <span class="mwe-math-mathml-inline mwe-math-mathml-a11y" style="display: none;">
          <math alttext="{\displaystyle e}" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML">
           <semantics>
            <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
             <mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0">
              <mi>
               e
              </mi>
             </mstyle>
            </mrow>
            <annotation encoding="application/x-tex">
             {\displaystyle e}
            </annotation>
           </semantics>
          </math>
         </span>
         <img alt=" e " aria-hidden="true" class="mwe-math-fallback-image-inline" src="https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/cd253103f0876afc68ebead27a5aa9867d927467" style="vertical-align: -0.338ex; width:1.083ex; height:1.676ex;"/>
        </span>
        is the
        <a href="/wiki/Orbital_eccentricity" title="Orbital eccentricity">
         orbital eccentricity
        </a>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Orbital_decay">
        Orbital decay
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=General_relativity&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: Orbital decay">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Psr1913%2B16-weisberg_en.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="483" data-file-width="415" height="256" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Psr1913%2B16-weisberg_en.png/220px-Psr1913%2B16-weisberg_en.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Psr1913%2B16-weisberg_en.png/330px-Psr1913%2B16-weisberg_en.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/7/79/Psr1913%2B16-weisberg_en.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Psr1913%2B16-weisberg_en.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Orbital decay for PSR1913+16: time shift in seconds, tracked over three decades.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86">
          <a href="#cite_note-86">
           [86]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       According to general relativity, a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Binary_system_(astronomy)" title="Binary system (astronomy)">
        binary system
       </a>
       will emit gravitational waves, thereby losing energy. Due to this loss, the distance between the two orbiting bodies decreases, and so does their orbital period. Within the
       <a href="/wiki/Solar_System" title="Solar System">
        Solar System
       </a>
       or for ordinary
       <a href="/wiki/Double_star" title="Double star">
        double stars
       </a>
       , the effect is too small to be observable. This is not the case for a close binary pulsar, a system of two orbiting
       <a href="/wiki/Neutron_star" title="Neutron star">
        neutron stars
       </a>
       , one of which is a pulsar: from the pulsar, observers on Earth receive a regular series of radio pulses that can serve as a highly accurate clock, which allows precise measurements of the orbital period. Because neutron stars are immensely compact, significant amounts of energy are emitted in the form of gravitational radiation.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87">
        <a href="#cite_note-87">
         [87]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The first observation of a decrease in orbital period due to the emission of gravitational waves was made by
       <a href="/wiki/Russell_Alan_Hulse" title="Russell Alan Hulse">
        Hulse
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Joseph_Hooton_Taylor,_Jr." title="Joseph Hooton Taylor, Jr.">
        Taylor
       </a>
       , using the binary pulsar
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PSR1913%2B16" title="PSR1913+16">
        PSR1913+16
       </a>
       they had discovered in 1974. This was the first detection of gravitational waves, albeit indirect, for which they were awarded the 1993
       <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize" title="Nobel Prize">
        Nobel Prize
       </a>
       in physics.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88">
        <a href="#cite_note-88">
         [88]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Since then, several other binary pulsars have been found, in particular the double pulsar
       <a href="/wiki/PSR_J0737-3039" title="PSR J0737-3039">
        PSR J0737-3039
       </a>
       , in which both stars are pulsars.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89">
        <a href="#cite_note-89">
         [89]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Geodetic_precession_and_frame-dragging">
        Geodetic precession and frame-dragging
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=General_relativity&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: Geodetic precession and frame-dragging">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Geodetic_precession" title="Geodetic precession">
        Geodetic precession
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Frame_dragging" title="Frame dragging">
        Frame dragging
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Several relativistic effects are directly related to the relativity of direction.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90">
        <a href="#cite_note-90">
         [90]
        </a>
       </sup>
       One is
       <a href="/wiki/Geodetic_effect" title="Geodetic effect">
        geodetic precession
       </a>
       : the axis direction of a
       <a href="/wiki/Gyroscope" title="Gyroscope">
        gyroscope
       </a>
       in free fall in curved spacetime will change when compared, for instance, with the direction of light received from distant stars—even though such a gyroscope represents the way of keeping a direction as stable as possible ("
       <a href="/wiki/Parallel_transport" title="Parallel transport">
        parallel transport
       </a>
       ").
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91">
        <a href="#cite_note-91">
         [91]
        </a>
       </sup>
       For the Moon–Earth system, this effect has been measured with the help of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lunar_laser_ranging" title="Lunar laser ranging">
        lunar laser ranging
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92">
        <a href="#cite_note-92">
         [92]
        </a>
       </sup>
       More recently, it has been measured for test masses aboard the satellite
       <a href="/wiki/Gravity_Probe_B" title="Gravity Probe B">
        Gravity Probe B
       </a>
       to a precision of better than 0.3%.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93">
        <a href="#cite_note-93">
         [93]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94">
        <a href="#cite_note-94">
         [94]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Near a rotating mass, there are gravitomagnetic or
       <a href="/wiki/Frame-dragging" title="Frame-dragging">
        frame-dragging
       </a>
       effects. A distant observer will determine that objects close to the mass get "dragged around". This is most extreme for
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kerr_solution" title="Kerr solution">
        rotating black holes
       </a>
       where, for any object entering a zone known as the
       <a href="/wiki/Ergosphere" title="Ergosphere">
        ergosphere
       </a>
       , rotation is inevitable.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95">
        <a href="#cite_note-95">
         [95]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Such effects can again be tested through their influence on the orientation of gyroscopes in free fall.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96">
        <a href="#cite_note-96">
         [96]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Somewhat controversial tests have been performed using the
       <a href="/wiki/LAGEOS" title="LAGEOS">
        LAGEOS
       </a>
       satellites, confirming the relativistic prediction.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97">
        <a href="#cite_note-97">
         [97]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Also the
       <a href="/wiki/Mars_Global_Surveyor" title="Mars Global Surveyor">
        Mars Global Surveyor
       </a>
       probe around Mars has been used.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98">
        <a href="#cite_note-98">
         [98]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99">
        <a href="#cite_note-99">
         [99]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Astrophysical_applications">
        Astrophysical applications
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=General_relativity&amp;action=edit&amp;section=18" title="Edit section: Astrophysical applications">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Gravitational_lensing">
        Gravitational lensing
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=General_relativity&amp;action=edit&amp;section=19" title="Edit section: Gravitational lensing">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gravitational_lensing" title="Gravitational lensing">
        Gravitational lensing
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Einstein_cross.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1849" data-file-width="1915" height="212" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Einstein_cross.jpg/220px-Einstein_cross.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Einstein_cross.jpg/330px-Einstein_cross.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Einstein_cross.jpg/440px-Einstein_cross.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Einstein_cross.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Einstein_cross" title="Einstein cross">
          Einstein cross
         </a>
         : four images of the same astronomical object, produced by a gravitational lens
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The deflection of light by gravity is responsible for a new class of astronomical phenomena. If a massive object is situated between the astronomer and a distant target object with appropriate mass and relative distances, the astronomer will see multiple distorted images of the target. Such effects are known as gravitational lensing.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100">
        <a href="#cite_note-100">
         [100]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Depending on the configuration, scale, and mass distribution, there can be two or more images, a bright ring known as an
       <a href="/wiki/Einstein_ring" title="Einstein ring">
        Einstein ring
       </a>
       , or partial rings called arcs.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101">
        <a href="#cite_note-101">
         [101]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Twin_Quasar" title="Twin Quasar">
        earliest example
       </a>
       was discovered in 1979;
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102">
        <a href="#cite_note-102">
         [102]
        </a>
       </sup>
       since then, more than a hundred gravitational lenses have been observed.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-103">
        <a href="#cite_note-103">
         [103]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Even if the multiple images are too close to each other to be resolved, the effect can still be measured, e.g., as an overall brightening of the target object; a number of such "
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Microlensing" title="Microlensing">
        microlensing
       </a>
       events" have been observed.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104">
        <a href="#cite_note-104">
         [104]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Gravitational lensing has developed into a tool of
       <a href="/wiki/Observational_astronomy" title="Observational astronomy">
        observational astronomy
       </a>
       . It is used to detect the presence and distribution of
       <a href="/wiki/Dark_matter" title="Dark matter">
        dark matter
       </a>
       , provide a "natural telescope" for observing distant galaxies, and to obtain an independent estimate of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hubble_constant" title="Hubble constant">
        Hubble constant
       </a>
       . Statistical evaluations of lensing data provide valuable insight into the structural evolution of
       <a href="/wiki/Galaxy" title="Galaxy">
        galaxies
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105">
        <a href="#cite_note-105">
         [105]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Gravitational_wave_astronomy">
        Gravitational wave astronomy
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=General_relativity&amp;action=edit&amp;section=20" title="Edit section: Gravitational wave astronomy">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Gravitational_wave" title="Gravitational wave">
        Gravitational wave
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gravitational_wave_astronomy" title="Gravitational wave astronomy">
        Gravitational wave astronomy
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:LISA.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="579" data-file-width="450" height="232" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/LISA.jpg/180px-LISA.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/LISA.jpg/270px-LISA.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/LISA.jpg/360px-LISA.jpg 2x" width="180"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:LISA.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Artist's impression of the space-borne gravitational wave detector
         <a href="/wiki/Laser_Interferometer_Space_Antenna" title="Laser Interferometer Space Antenna">
          LISA
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Observations of binary pulsars provide strong indirect evidence for the existence of gravitational waves (see
       <a href="/wiki/General_relativity#Orbital_decay" title="General relativity">
        Orbital decay
       </a>
       , above). Detection of these waves is a major goal of current relativity-related research.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106">
        <a href="#cite_note-106">
         [106]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Several land-based
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gravitational_wave_detector" title="Gravitational wave detector">
        gravitational wave detectors
       </a>
       are currently in operation, most notably the
       <a href="/wiki/Interferometric_gravitational_wave_detector" title="Interferometric gravitational wave detector">
        interferometric detectors
       </a>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/GEO_600" title="GEO 600">
        GEO 600
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/LIGO" title="LIGO">
        LIGO
       </a>
       (two detectors),
       <a href="/wiki/TAMA_300" title="TAMA 300">
        TAMA 300
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Virgo_interferometer" title="Virgo interferometer">
        VIRGO
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107">
        <a href="#cite_note-107">
         [107]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Various
       <a href="/wiki/Pulsar_timing_array" title="Pulsar timing array">
        pulsar timing arrays
       </a>
       are using
       <a href="/wiki/Millisecond_pulsar" title="Millisecond pulsar">
        millisecond pulsars
       </a>
       to detect gravitational waves in the 10
       <sup>
        −9
       </sup>
       to 10
       <sup>
        −6
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Hertz" title="Hertz">
        Hertz
       </a>
       frequency range, which originate from binary supermassive blackholes.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108">
        <a href="#cite_note-108">
         [108]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A European space-based detector,
       <a href="/wiki/Laser_Interferometer_Space_Antenna" title="Laser Interferometer Space Antenna">
        eLISA / NGO
       </a>
       , is currently under development,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109">
        <a href="#cite_note-109">
         [109]
        </a>
       </sup>
       with a precursor mission (
       <a href="/wiki/LISA_Pathfinder" title="LISA Pathfinder">
        LISA Pathfinder
       </a>
       ) having launched in December 2015.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110">
        <a href="#cite_note-110">
         [110]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Observations of gravitational waves promise to complement observations in the
       <a href="/wiki/Electromagnetic_spectrum" title="Electromagnetic spectrum">
        electromagnetic spectrum
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111">
        <a href="#cite_note-111">
         [111]
        </a>
       </sup>
       They are expected to yield information about black holes and other dense objects such as neutron stars and white dwarfs, about certain kinds of
       <a href="/wiki/Supernova" title="Supernova">
        supernova
       </a>
       implosions, and about processes in the very early universe, including the signature of certain types of hypothetical
       <a href="/wiki/Cosmic_string" title="Cosmic string">
        cosmic string
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112">
        <a href="#cite_note-112">
         [112]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In February 2016, the Advanced LIGO team announced that they had detected gravitational waves from a black hole merger.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Discovery_2016_71-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Discovery_2016-71">
         [71]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Abbot_72-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Abbot-72">
         [72]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113">
        <a href="#cite_note-113">
         [113]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Black_holes_and_other_compact_objects">
        Black holes and other compact objects
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=General_relativity&amp;action=edit&amp;section=21" title="Edit section: Black holes and other compact objects">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Black_hole" title="Black hole">
        Black hole
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Whenever the ratio of an object's mass to its radius becomes sufficiently large, general relativity predicts the formation of a black hole, a region of space from which nothing, not even light, can escape. In the currently accepted models of
       <a href="/wiki/Stellar_evolution" title="Stellar evolution">
        stellar evolution
       </a>
       , neutron stars of around 1.4
       <a href="/wiki/Solar_mass" title="Solar mass">
        solar masses
       </a>
       , and stellar black holes with a few to a few dozen solar masses, are thought to be the final state for the evolution of massive stars.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114">
        <a href="#cite_note-114">
         [114]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Usually a galaxy has one supermassive black hole with a few million to a few
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1000000000_(number)" title="1000000000 (number)">
        billion
       </a>
       solar masses in its center,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115">
        <a href="#cite_note-115">
         [115]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and its presence is thought to have played an important role in the formation of the galaxy and larger cosmic structures.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116">
        <a href="#cite_note-116">
         [116]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Star_collapse_to_black_hole.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="308" data-file-width="500" height="136" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Star_collapse_to_black_hole.png/220px-Star_collapse_to_black_hole.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Star_collapse_to_black_hole.png/330px-Star_collapse_to_black_hole.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Star_collapse_to_black_hole.png/440px-Star_collapse_to_black_hole.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Star_collapse_to_black_hole.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Simulation based on the equations of general relativity: a star collapsing to form a black hole while emitting gravitational waves
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Astronomically, the most important property of compact objects is that they provide a supremely efficient mechanism for converting gravitational energy into electromagnetic radiation.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117">
        <a href="#cite_note-117">
         [117]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Accretion_(astrophysics)" title="Accretion (astrophysics)">
        Accretion
       </a>
       , the falling of dust or gaseous matter onto stellar or supermassive black holes, is thought to be responsible for some spectacularly luminous astronomical objects, notably diverse kinds of active galactic nuclei on galactic scales and stellar-size objects such as microquasars.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118">
        <a href="#cite_note-118">
         [118]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In particular, accretion can lead to
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Relativistic_jet" title="Relativistic jet">
        relativistic jets
       </a>
       , focused beams of highly energetic particles that are being flung into space at almost light speed.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119">
        <a href="#cite_note-119">
         [119]
        </a>
       </sup>
       General relativity plays a central role in modelling all these phenomena,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120">
        <a href="#cite_note-120">
         [120]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and observations provide strong evidence for the existence of black holes with the properties predicted by the theory.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121">
        <a href="#cite_note-121">
         [121]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Black holes are also sought-after targets in the search for gravitational waves (cf.
       <a href="/wiki/General_relativity#Gravitational_waves" title="General relativity">
        Gravitational waves
       </a>
       , above). Merging
       <a href="/wiki/Binary_black_hole" title="Binary black hole">
        black hole binaries
       </a>
       should lead to some of the strongest gravitational wave signals reaching detectors here on Earth, and the phase directly before the merger ("chirp") could be used as a "
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Standard_candle" title="Standard candle">
        standard candle
       </a>
       " to deduce the distance to the merger events–and hence serve as a probe of cosmic expansion at large distances.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122">
        <a href="#cite_note-122">
         [122]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The gravitational waves produced as a stellar black hole plunges into a supermassive one should provide direct information about the supermassive black hole's geometry.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123">
        <a href="#cite_note-123">
         [123]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div style="clear:both;">
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Cosmology">
        Cosmology
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=General_relativity&amp;action=edit&amp;section=22" title="Edit section: Cosmology">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lensshoe_hubble.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2572" data-file-width="3235" height="175" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Lensshoe_hubble.jpg/220px-Lensshoe_hubble.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Lensshoe_hubble.jpg/330px-Lensshoe_hubble.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Lensshoe_hubble.jpg/440px-Lensshoe_hubble.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lensshoe_hubble.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         This blue horseshoe is a distant galaxy that has been magnified and warped into a nearly complete ring by the strong gravitational pull of the massive foreground
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Luminous_red_galaxy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Luminous red galaxy (page does not exist)">
          luminous red galaxy
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Physical_cosmology" title="Physical cosmology">
        Physical cosmology
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       The current models of cosmology are based on
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Einstein%27s_field_equations" title="Einstein's field equations">
        Einstein's field equations
       </a>
       , which include the cosmological constant Λ since it has important influence on the large-scale dynamics of the cosmos,
      </p>
      <dl>
       <dd>
        <span class="mwe-math-element">
         <span class="mwe-math-mathml-inline mwe-math-mathml-a11y" style="display: none;">
          <math alttext="{\displaystyle R_{\mu \nu }-{\textstyle 1 \over 2}R\,g_{\mu \nu }+\Lambda \ g_{\mu \nu }={\frac {8\pi G}{c^{4}}}\,T_{\mu \nu }}" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML">
           <semantics>
            <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
             <mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0">
              <msub>
               <mi>
                R
               </mi>
               <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
                <mi>
                 μ
                 <!-- μ -->
                </mi>
                <mi>
                 ν
                 <!-- ν -->
                </mi>
               </mrow>
              </msub>
              <mo>
               −
               <!-- − -->
              </mo>
              <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
               <mfrac>
                <mstyle displaystyle="false" scriptlevel="0">
                 <mn>
                  1
                 </mn>
                </mstyle>
                <mn>
                 2
                </mn>
               </mfrac>
              </mrow>
              <mi>
               R
              </mi>
              <mspace width="thinmathspace">
              </mspace>
              <msub>
               <mi>
                g
               </mi>
               <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
                <mi>
                 μ
                 <!-- μ -->
                </mi>
                <mi>
                 ν
                 <!-- ν -->
                </mi>
               </mrow>
              </msub>
              <mo>
               +
              </mo>
              <mi mathvariant="normal">
               Λ
               <!-- Λ -->
              </mi>
              <mtext>
              </mtext>
              <msub>
               <mi>
                g
               </mi>
               <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
                <mi>
                 μ
                 <!-- μ -->
                </mi>
                <mi>
                 ν
                 <!-- ν -->
                </mi>
               </mrow>
              </msub>
              <mo>
               =
              </mo>
              <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
               <mfrac>
                <mrow>
                 <mn>
                  8
                 </mn>
                 <mi>
                  π
                  <!-- π -->
                 </mi>
                 <mi>
                  G
                 </mi>
                </mrow>
                <msup>
                 <mi>
                  c
                 </mi>
                 <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
                  <mn>
                   4
                  </mn>
                 </mrow>
                </msup>
               </mfrac>
              </mrow>
              <mspace width="thinmathspace">
              </mspace>
              <msub>
               <mi>
                T
               </mi>
               <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
                <mi>
                 μ
                 <!-- μ -->
                </mi>
                <mi>
                 ν
                 <!-- ν -->
                </mi>
               </mrow>
              </msub>
             </mstyle>
            </mrow>
            <annotation encoding="application/x-tex">
             {\displaystyle R_{\mu \nu }-{\textstyle 1 \over 2}R\,g_{\mu \nu }+\Lambda \ g_{\mu \nu }={\frac {8\pi G}{c^{4}}}\,T_{\mu \nu }}
            </annotation>
           </semantics>
          </math>
         </span>
         <img alt="R_{\mu \nu }-{\textstyle 1 \over 2}R\,g_{\mu \nu }+\Lambda \ g_{\mu \nu }={\frac {8\pi G}{c^{4}}}\,T_{\mu \nu }" aria-hidden="true" class="mwe-math-fallback-image-inline" src="https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/b90cd8fb6edf598f64c45bf2bfce258dce51de6e" style="vertical-align: -2.171ex; width:34.385ex; height:5.676ex;"/>
        </span>
       </dd>
      </dl>
      <p>
       where
       <i>
        <span class="mwe-math-element">
         <span class="mwe-math-mathml-inline mwe-math-mathml-a11y" style="display: none;">
          <math alttext="{\displaystyle g_{\mu \nu }}" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML">
           <semantics>
            <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
             <mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0">
              <msub>
               <mi>
                g
               </mi>
               <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
                <mi>
                 μ
                 <!-- μ -->
                </mi>
                <mi>
                 ν
                 <!-- ν -->
                </mi>
               </mrow>
              </msub>
             </mstyle>
            </mrow>
            <annotation encoding="application/x-tex">
             {\displaystyle g_{\mu \nu }}
            </annotation>
           </semantics>
          </math>
         </span>
         <img alt="g_{\mu \nu }" aria-hidden="true" class="mwe-math-fallback-image-inline" src="https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/e5bf4140993a891f5782167dc8a0c236dc7667b8" style="vertical-align: -1.005ex; width:3.204ex; height:2.343ex;"/>
        </span>
       </i>
       is the spacetime metric.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124">
        <a href="#cite_note-124">
         [124]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Isotropic" title="Isotropic">
        Isotropic
       </a>
       and homogeneous solutions of these enhanced equations, the Friedmann–Lemaître–Robertson–Walker solutions,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125">
        <a href="#cite_note-125">
         [125]
        </a>
       </sup>
       allow physicists to model a universe that has evolved over the past 14
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1000000000_(number)" title="1000000000 (number)">
        billion
       </a>
       years from a hot, early Big Bang phase.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126">
        <a href="#cite_note-126">
         [126]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Once a small number of parameters (for example the universe's mean matter density) have been fixed by astronomical observation,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127">
        <a href="#cite_note-127">
         [127]
        </a>
       </sup>
       further observational data can be used to put the models to the test.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128">
        <a href="#cite_note-128">
         [128]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Predictions, all successful, include the initial abundance of chemical elements formed in a period of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Big_bang_nucleosynthesis" title="Big bang nucleosynthesis">
        primordial nucleosynthesis
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129">
        <a href="#cite_note-129">
         [129]
        </a>
       </sup>
       the large-scale structure of the universe,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130">
        <a href="#cite_note-130">
         [130]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and the existence and properties of a "
       <a href="/wiki/Thermal_radiation" title="Thermal radiation">
        thermal
       </a>
       echo" from the early cosmos, the
       <a href="/wiki/Cosmic_background_radiation" title="Cosmic background radiation">
        cosmic background radiation
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131">
        <a href="#cite_note-131">
         [131]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Astronomical observations of the cosmological expansion rate allow the total amount of matter in the universe to be estimated, although the nature of that matter remains mysterious in part. About 90% of all matter appears to be dark matter, which has mass (or, equivalently, gravitational influence), but does not interact electromagnetically and, hence, cannot be observed directly.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132">
        <a href="#cite_note-132">
         [132]
        </a>
       </sup>
       There is no generally accepted description of this new kind of matter, within the framework of known
       <a href="/wiki/Particle_physics" title="Particle physics">
        particle physics
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133">
        <a href="#cite_note-133">
         [133]
        </a>
       </sup>
       or otherwise.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134">
        <a href="#cite_note-134">
         [134]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Observational evidence from redshift surveys of distant supernovae and measurements of the cosmic background radiation also show that the evolution of our universe is significantly influenced by a cosmological constant resulting in an acceleration of cosmic expansion or, equivalently, by a form of energy with an unusual
       <a href="/wiki/Equation_of_state" title="Equation of state">
        equation of state
       </a>
       , known as
       <a href="/wiki/Dark_energy" title="Dark energy">
        dark energy
       </a>
       , the nature of which remains unclear.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135">
        <a href="#cite_note-135">
         [135]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       An
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cosmic_inflation" title="Cosmic inflation">
        inflationary phase
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136">
        <a href="#cite_note-136">
         [136]
        </a>
       </sup>
       an additional phase of strongly accelerated expansion at cosmic times of around 10
       <sup>
        −33
       </sup>
       seconds, was hypothesized in 1980 to account for several puzzling observations that were unexplained by classical cosmological models, such as the nearly perfect homogeneity of the cosmic background radiation.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137">
        <a href="#cite_note-137">
         [137]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Recent measurements of the cosmic background radiation have resulted in the first evidence for this scenario.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138">
        <a href="#cite_note-138">
         [138]
        </a>
       </sup>
       However, there is a bewildering variety of possible inflationary scenarios, which cannot be restricted by current observations.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139">
        <a href="#cite_note-139">
         [139]
        </a>
       </sup>
       An even larger question is the physics of the earliest universe, prior to the inflationary phase and close to where the classical models predict the big bang
       <a href="/wiki/Gravitational_singularity" title="Gravitational singularity">
        singularity
       </a>
       . An authoritative answer would require a complete theory of quantum gravity, which has not yet been developed
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140">
        <a href="#cite_note-140">
         [140]
        </a>
       </sup>
       (cf. the section on
       <a href="/wiki/General_relativity#Quantum_gravity" title="General relativity">
        quantum gravity
       </a>
       , below).
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Time_travel">
        Time travel
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=General_relativity&amp;action=edit&amp;section=23" title="Edit section: Time travel">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Kurt_G%C3%B6del" title="Kurt Gödel">
        Kurt Gödel
       </a>
       showed
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141">
        <a href="#cite_note-141">
         [141]
        </a>
       </sup>
       that solutions to Einstein's equations exist that contain
       <a href="/wiki/Closed_timelike_curve" title="Closed timelike curve">
        closed timelike curves
       </a>
       (CTCs), which allow for loops in time. The solutions require extreme physical conditions unlikely ever to occur in practice, and it remains an open question whether further laws of physics will eliminate them completely. Since then, other—similarly impractical—GR solutions containing CTCs have been found, such as the
       <a href="/wiki/Tipler_cylinder" title="Tipler cylinder">
        Tipler cylinder
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Wormhole#Traversable_wormholes" title="Wormhole">
        traversable wormholes
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Advanced_concepts">
        Advanced concepts
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=General_relativity&amp;action=edit&amp;section=24" title="Edit section: Advanced concepts">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Causal_structure_and_global_geometry">
        Causal structure and global geometry
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=General_relativity&amp;action=edit&amp;section=25" title="Edit section: Causal structure and global geometry">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Causal_structure" title="Causal structure">
        Causal structure
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Penrose.svg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="588" data-file-width="651" height="199" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Penrose.svg/220px-Penrose.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Penrose.svg/330px-Penrose.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Penrose.svg/440px-Penrose.svg.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Penrose.svg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Penrose–Carter diagram of an infinite
         <a href="/wiki/Minkowski_space" title="Minkowski space">
          Minkowski universe
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       In general relativity, no material body can catch up with or overtake a light pulse. No influence from an event A can reach any other location X before light sent out at A to X. In consequence, an exploration of all light worldlines (
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Geodesic_(general_relativity)" title="Geodesic (general relativity)">
        null geodesics
       </a>
       ) yields key information about the spacetime's causal structure. This structure can be displayed using
       <a href="/wiki/Penrose_diagram" title="Penrose diagram">
        Penrose–Carter diagrams
       </a>
       in which infinitely large regions of space and infinite time intervals are shrunk ("
       <a href="/wiki/Compactification_(mathematics)" title="Compactification (mathematics)">
        compactified
       </a>
       ") so as to fit onto a finite map, while light still travels along diagonals as in standard
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Spacetime_diagram" title="Spacetime diagram">
        spacetime diagrams
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142">
        <a href="#cite_note-142">
         [142]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Aware of the importance of causal structure,
       <a href="/wiki/Roger_Penrose" title="Roger Penrose">
        Roger Penrose
       </a>
       and others developed what is known as
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Global_geometry" title="Global geometry">
        global geometry
       </a>
       . In global geometry, the object of study is not one particular solution (or family of solutions) to Einstein's equations. Rather, relations that hold true for all geodesics, such as the
       <a href="/wiki/Raychaudhuri_equation" title="Raychaudhuri equation">
        Raychaudhuri equation
       </a>
       , and additional non-specific assumptions about the nature of matter (usually in the form of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Energy_conditions" title="Energy conditions">
        energy conditions
       </a>
       ) are used to derive general results.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143">
        <a href="#cite_note-143">
         [143]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Horizons">
        Horizons
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=General_relativity&amp;action=edit&amp;section=26" title="Edit section: Horizons">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Horizon_(general_relativity)" title="Horizon (general relativity)">
        Horizon (general relativity)
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/No_hair_theorem" title="No hair theorem">
        No hair theorem
       </a>
       , and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Black_hole_mechanics" title="Black hole mechanics">
        Black hole mechanics
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Using global geometry, some spacetimes can be shown to contain boundaries called
       <a href="/wiki/Event_horizon" title="Event horizon">
        horizons
       </a>
       , which demarcate one region from the rest of spacetime. The best-known examples are black holes: if mass is compressed into a sufficiently compact region of space (as specified in the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hoop_conjecture" title="Hoop conjecture">
        hoop conjecture
       </a>
       , the relevant length scale is the
       <a href="/wiki/Schwarzschild_radius" title="Schwarzschild radius">
        Schwarzschild radius
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144">
        <a href="#cite_note-144">
         [144]
        </a>
       </sup>
       ), no light from inside can escape to the outside. Since no object can overtake a light pulse, all interior matter is imprisoned as well. Passage from the exterior to the interior is still possible, showing that the boundary, the black hole's
       <i>
        horizon
       </i>
       , is not a physical barrier.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145">
        <a href="#cite_note-145">
         [145]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ergosphere.svg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1660" data-file-width="1645" height="222" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Ergosphere.svg/220px-Ergosphere.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Ergosphere.svg/330px-Ergosphere.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Ergosphere.svg/440px-Ergosphere.svg.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ergosphere.svg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The ergosphere of a rotating black hole, which plays a key role when it comes to extracting energy from such a black hole
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Early studies of black holes relied on explicit solutions of Einstein's equations, notably the spherically symmetric Schwarzschild solution (used to describe a
       <a href="/wiki/Static_spacetime" title="Static spacetime">
        static
       </a>
       black hole) and the axisymmetric
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kerr_solution" title="Kerr solution">
        Kerr solution
       </a>
       (used to describe a rotating,
       <a href="/wiki/Stationary_spacetime" title="Stationary spacetime">
        stationary
       </a>
       black hole, and introducing interesting features such as the ergosphere). Using global geometry, later studies have revealed more general properties of black holes. In the long run, they are rather simple objects characterized by eleven parameters specifying energy,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Linear_momentum" title="Linear momentum">
        linear momentum
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Angular_momentum" title="Angular momentum">
        angular momentum
       </a>
       , location at a specified time and electric charge. This is stated by the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/No_hair_theorem" title="No hair theorem">
        black hole uniqueness theorems
       </a>
       : "black holes have no hair", that is, no distinguishing marks like the hairstyles of humans. Irrespective of the complexity of a gravitating object collapsing to form a black hole, the object that results (having emitted gravitational waves) is very simple.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146">
        <a href="#cite_note-146">
         [146]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Even more remarkably, there is a general set of laws known as
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Black_hole_mechanics" title="Black hole mechanics">
        black hole mechanics
       </a>
       , which is analogous to the
       <a href="/wiki/Laws_of_thermodynamics" title="Laws of thermodynamics">
        laws of thermodynamics
       </a>
       . For instance, by the second law of black hole mechanics, the area of the event horizon of a general black hole will never decrease with time, analogous to the
       <a href="/wiki/Entropy" title="Entropy">
        entropy
       </a>
       of a thermodynamic system. This limits the energy that can be extracted by classical means from a rotating black hole (e.g. by the
       <a href="/wiki/Penrose_process" title="Penrose process">
        Penrose process
       </a>
       ).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147">
        <a href="#cite_note-147">
         [147]
        </a>
       </sup>
       There is strong evidence that the laws of black hole mechanics are, in fact, a subset of the laws of thermodynamics, and that the black hole area is proportional to its entropy.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-148">
        <a href="#cite_note-148">
         [148]
        </a>
       </sup>
       This leads to a modification of the original laws of black hole mechanics: for instance, as the second law of black hole mechanics becomes part of the second law of thermodynamics, it is possible for black hole area to decrease—as long as other processes ensure that, overall, entropy increases. As thermodynamical objects with non-zero temperature, black holes should emit
       <a href="/wiki/Thermal_radiation" title="Thermal radiation">
        thermal radiation
       </a>
       . Semi-classical calculations indicate that indeed they do, with the surface gravity playing the role of temperature in
       <a href="/wiki/Planck%27s_law" title="Planck's law">
        Planck's law
       </a>
       . This radiation is known as
       <a href="/wiki/Hawking_radiation" title="Hawking radiation">
        Hawking radiation
       </a>
       (cf. the
       <a href="/wiki/General_relativity#Quantum_field_theory_in_curved_spacetime" title="General relativity">
        quantum theory section
       </a>
       , below).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149">
        <a href="#cite_note-149">
         [149]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       There are other types of horizons. In an expanding universe, an observer may find that some regions of the past cannot be observed ("
       <a href="/wiki/Particle_horizon" title="Particle horizon">
        particle horizon
       </a>
       "), and some regions of the future cannot be influenced (event horizon).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150">
        <a href="#cite_note-150">
         [150]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Even in flat Minkowski space, when described by an accelerated observer (
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rindler_space" title="Rindler space">
        Rindler space
       </a>
       ), there will be horizons associated with a semi-classical radiation known as
       <a href="/wiki/Unruh_effect" title="Unruh effect">
        Unruh radiation
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151">
        <a href="#cite_note-151">
         [151]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Singularities">
        Singularities
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=General_relativity&amp;action=edit&amp;section=27" title="Edit section: Singularities">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Spacetime_singularity" title="Spacetime singularity">
        Spacetime singularity
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Another general feature of general relativity is the appearance of spacetime boundaries known as singularities. Spacetime can be explored by following up on timelike and lightlike geodesics—all possible ways that light and particles in free fall can travel.
