But some solutions of Einstein's equations have "ragged edges"—regions known as
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Spacetime_singularity" title="Spacetime singularity">
        spacetime singularities
       </a>
       , where the paths of light and falling particles come to an abrupt end, and geometry becomes ill-defined. In the more interesting cases, these are "curvature singularities", where geometrical quantities characterizing spacetime curvature, such as the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ricci_scalar" title="Ricci scalar">
        Ricci scalar
       </a>
       , take on infinite values.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152">
        <a href="#cite_note-152">
         [152]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Well-known examples of spacetimes with future singularities—where worldlines end—are the Schwarzschild solution, which describes a singularity inside an eternal static black hole,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153">
        <a href="#cite_note-153">
         [153]
        </a>
       </sup>
       or the Kerr solution with its ring-shaped singularity inside an eternal rotating black hole.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154">
        <a href="#cite_note-154">
         [154]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Friedmann–Lemaître–Robertson–Walker solutions and other spacetimes describing universes have past singularities on which worldlines begin, namely Big Bang singularities, and some have future singularities (
       <a href="/wiki/Big_Crunch" title="Big Crunch">
        Big Crunch
       </a>
       ) as well.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155">
        <a href="#cite_note-155">
         [155]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Given that these examples are all highly symmetric—and thus simplified—it is tempting to conclude that the occurrence of singularities is an artifact of idealization.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156">
        <a href="#cite_note-156">
         [156]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The famous
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Singularity_theorems" title="Singularity theorems">
        singularity theorems
       </a>
       , proved using the methods of global geometry, say otherwise: singularities are a generic feature of general relativity, and unavoidable once the collapse of an object with realistic matter properties has proceeded beyond a certain stage
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157">
        <a href="#cite_note-157">
         [157]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and also at the beginning of a wide class of expanding universes.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-158">
        <a href="#cite_note-158">
         [158]
        </a>
       </sup>
       However, the theorems say little about the properties of singularities, and much of current research is devoted to characterizing these entities' generic structure (hypothesized e.g. by the
       <a href="/wiki/BKL_singularity" title="BKL singularity">
        BKL conjecture
       </a>
       ).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-159">
        <a href="#cite_note-159">
         [159]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Cosmic_censorship_hypothesis" title="Cosmic censorship hypothesis">
        cosmic censorship hypothesis
       </a>
       states that all realistic future singularities (no perfect symmetries, matter with realistic properties) are safely hidden away behind a horizon, and thus invisible to all distant observers. While no formal proof yet exists, numerical simulations offer supporting evidence of its validity.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160">
        <a href="#cite_note-160">
         [160]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Evolution_equations">
        Evolution equations
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=General_relativity&amp;action=edit&amp;section=28" title="Edit section: Evolution equations">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Initial_value_formulation_(general_relativity)" title="Initial value formulation (general relativity)">
        Initial value formulation (general relativity)
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Each solution of Einstein's equation encompasses the whole history of a universe — it is not just some snapshot of how things are, but a whole, possibly matter-filled, spacetime. It describes the state of matter and geometry everywhere and at every moment in that particular universe. Due to its general covariance, Einstein's theory is not sufficient by itself to determine the
       <a href="/wiki/Time_evolution" title="Time evolution">
        time evolution
       </a>
       of the metric tensor. It must be combined with a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Coordinate_condition" title="Coordinate condition">
        coordinate condition
       </a>
       , which is analogous to
       <a href="/wiki/Gauge_fixing" title="Gauge fixing">
        gauge fixing
       </a>
       in other field theories.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161">
        <a href="#cite_note-161">
         [161]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       To understand Einstein's equations as partial differential equations, it is helpful to formulate them in a way that describes the evolution of the universe over time. This is done in "3+1" formulations, where spacetime is split into three space dimensions and one time dimension. The best-known example is the
       <a href="/wiki/ADM_formalism" title="ADM formalism">
        ADM formalism
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162">
        <a href="#cite_note-162">
         [162]
        </a>
       </sup>
       These decompositions show that the spacetime evolution equations of general relativity are well-behaved: solutions always
       <a href="/wiki/Existence_theorem" title="Existence theorem">
        exist
       </a>
       , and are uniquely defined, once suitable initial conditions have been specified.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163">
        <a href="#cite_note-163">
         [163]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Such formulations of Einstein's field equations are the basis of numerical relativity.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164">
        <a href="#cite_note-164">
         [164]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Global_and_quasi-local_quantities">
        Global and quasi-local quantities
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=General_relativity&amp;action=edit&amp;section=29" title="Edit section: Global and quasi-local quantities">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Mass_in_general_relativity" title="Mass in general relativity">
        Mass in general relativity
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       The notion of evolution equations is intimately tied in with another aspect of general relativistic physics. In Einstein's theory, it turns out to be impossible to find a general definition for a seemingly simple property such as a system's total mass (or energy). The main reason is that the gravitational field—like any physical field—must be ascribed a certain energy, but that it proves to be fundamentally impossible to localize that energy.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165">
        <a href="#cite_note-165">
         [165]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Nevertheless, there are possibilities to define a system's total mass, either using a hypothetical "infinitely distant observer" (
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ADM_mass" title="ADM mass">
        ADM mass
       </a>
       )
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166">
        <a href="#cite_note-166">
         [166]
        </a>
       </sup>
       or suitable symmetries (
       <a href="/wiki/Komar_mass" title="Komar mass">
        Komar mass
       </a>
       ).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167">
        <a href="#cite_note-167">
         [167]
        </a>
       </sup>
       If one excludes from the system's total mass the energy being carried away to infinity by gravitational waves, the result is the
       <a href="/wiki/Mass_in_general_relativity#ADM_and_Bondi_masses_in_asymptotically_flat_space-times" title="Mass in general relativity">
        Bondi mass
       </a>
       at null infinity.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168">
        <a href="#cite_note-168">
         [168]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Just as in
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Physics_in_the_Classical_Limit" title="Physics in the Classical Limit">
        classical physics
       </a>
       , it can be shown that these masses are positive.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169">
        <a href="#cite_note-169">
         [169]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Corresponding global definitions exist for momentum and angular momentum.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170">
        <a href="#cite_note-170">
         [170]
        </a>
       </sup>
       There have also been a number of attempts to define
       <i>
        quasi-local
       </i>
       quantities, such as the mass of an isolated system formulated using only quantities defined within a finite region of space containing that system. The hope is to obtain a quantity useful for general statements about
       <a href="/wiki/Isolated_system" title="Isolated system">
        isolated systems
       </a>
       , such as a more precise formulation of the hoop conjecture.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171">
        <a href="#cite_note-171">
         [171]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Relationship_with_quantum_theory">
        Relationship with quantum theory
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=General_relativity&amp;action=edit&amp;section=30" title="Edit section: Relationship with quantum theory">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <p>
       If general relativity were considered to be one of the two pillars of modern physics, then quantum theory, the basis of understanding matter from elementary particles to
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Solid_state_physics" title="Solid state physics">
        solid state physics
       </a>
       , would be the other.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172">
        <a href="#cite_note-172">
         [172]
        </a>
       </sup>
       However, how to reconcile quantum theory with general relativity is still an open question.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Quantum_field_theory_in_curved_spacetime">
        Quantum field theory in curved spacetime
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=General_relativity&amp;action=edit&amp;section=31" title="Edit section: Quantum field theory in curved spacetime">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Quantum_field_theory_in_curved_spacetime" title="Quantum field theory in curved spacetime">
        Quantum field theory in curved spacetime
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Ordinary
       <a href="/wiki/Quantum_field_theory" title="Quantum field theory">
        quantum field theories
       </a>
       , which form the basis of modern elementary particle physics, are defined in flat Minkowski space, which is an excellent approximation when it comes to describing the behavior of microscopic particles in weak gravitational fields like those found on Earth.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173">
        <a href="#cite_note-173">
         [173]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In order to describe situations in which gravity is strong enough to influence (quantum) matter, yet not strong enough to require quantization itself, physicists have formulated quantum field theories in curved spacetime. These theories rely on general relativity to describe a curved background spacetime, and define a generalized quantum field theory to describe the behavior of quantum matter within that spacetime.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174">
        <a href="#cite_note-174">
         [174]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Using this formalism, it can be shown that black holes emit a blackbody spectrum of particles known as
       <a href="/wiki/Hawking_radiation" title="Hawking radiation">
        Hawking radiation
       </a>
       leading to the possibility that they
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Black_hole_evaporation" title="Black hole evaporation">
        evaporate
       </a>
       over time.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175">
        <a href="#cite_note-175">
         [175]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As briefly mentioned
       <a href="/wiki/General_relativity#Horizons" title="General relativity">
        above
       </a>
       , this radiation plays an important role for the thermodynamics of black holes.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176">
        <a href="#cite_note-176">
         [176]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Quantum_gravity">
        Quantum gravity
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=General_relativity&amp;action=edit&amp;section=32" title="Edit section: Quantum gravity">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Quantum_gravity" title="Quantum gravity">
        Quantum gravity
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/String_theory" title="String theory">
        String theory
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Canonical_general_relativity" title="Canonical general relativity">
        Canonical general relativity
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Loop_quantum_gravity" title="Loop quantum gravity">
        Loop quantum gravity
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Causal_Dynamical_Triangulations" title="Causal Dynamical Triangulations">
        Causal Dynamical Triangulations
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Causal_sets" title="Causal sets">
        Causal sets
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       The demand for consistency between a quantum description of matter and a geometric description of spacetime,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177">
        <a href="#cite_note-177">
         [177]
        </a>
       </sup>
       as well as the appearance of singularities (where curvature length scales become microscopic), indicate the need for a full theory of quantum gravity: for an adequate description of the interior of black holes, and of the very early universe, a theory is required in which gravity and the associated geometry of spacetime are described in the language of quantum physics.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178">
        <a href="#cite_note-178">
         [178]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Despite major efforts, no complete and consistent theory of quantum gravity is currently known, even though a number of promising candidates exist.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hamber_2009_179-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Hamber_2009-179">
         [179]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180">
        <a href="#cite_note-180">
         [180]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Calabi_yau.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1493" data-file-width="1432" height="229" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Calabi_yau.jpg/220px-Calabi_yau.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Calabi_yau.jpg/330px-Calabi_yau.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Calabi_yau.jpg/440px-Calabi_yau.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Calabi_yau.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Projection of a
         <a href="/wiki/Calabi%E2%80%93Yau_manifold" title="Calabi–Yau manifold">
          Calabi–Yau manifold
         </a>
         , one of the ways of
         <a href="/wiki/Compactification_(physics)" title="Compactification (physics)">
          compactifying
         </a>
         the extra dimensions posited by string theory
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Attempts to generalize ordinary quantum field theories, used in elementary particle physics to describe fundamental interactions, so as to include gravity have led to serious problems.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181">
        <a href="#cite_note-181">
         [181]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Some have argued that at low energies, this approach proves successful, in that it results in an acceptable
       <a href="/wiki/Effective_field_theory" title="Effective field theory">
        effective (quantum) field theory
       </a>
       of gravity.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182">
        <a href="#cite_note-182">
         [182]
        </a>
       </sup>
       At very high energies, however, the perturbative results are badly divergent and lead to models devoid of predictive power ("perturbative
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Non-renormalizable" title="Non-renormalizable">
        non-renormalizability
       </a>
       ").
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183">
        <a href="#cite_note-183">
         [183]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Spin_network.svg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="964" data-file-width="702" height="302" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Spin_network.svg/220px-Spin_network.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Spin_network.svg/330px-Spin_network.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Spin_network.svg/440px-Spin_network.svg.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Spin_network.svg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Simple
         <a href="/wiki/Spin_network" title="Spin network">
          spin network
         </a>
         of the type used in loop quantum gravity.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       One attempt to overcome these limitations is
       <a href="/wiki/String_theory" title="String theory">
        string theory
       </a>
       , a quantum theory not of
       <a href="/wiki/Point_particle" title="Point particle">
        point particles
       </a>
       , but of minute one-dimensional extended objects.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184">
        <a href="#cite_note-184">
         [184]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The theory promises to be a
       <a href="/wiki/Theory_of_everything" title="Theory of everything">
        unified description
       </a>
       of all particles and interactions, including gravity;
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185">
        <a href="#cite_note-185">
         [185]
        </a>
       </sup>
       the price to pay is unusual features such as six
       <a href="/wiki/Superstring_theory#Extra_dimensions" title="Superstring theory">
        extra dimensions
       </a>
       of space in addition to the usual three.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186">
        <a href="#cite_note-186">
         [186]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In what is called the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Second_superstring_revolution" title="Second superstring revolution">
        second superstring revolution
       </a>
       , it was conjectured that both string theory and a unification of general relativity and
       <a href="/wiki/Supersymmetry" title="Supersymmetry">
        supersymmetry
       </a>
       known as
       <a href="/wiki/Supergravity" title="Supergravity">
        supergravity
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187">
        <a href="#cite_note-187">
         [187]
        </a>
       </sup>
       form part of a hypothesized eleven-dimensional model known as
       <a href="/wiki/M-theory" title="M-theory">
        M-theory
       </a>
       , which would constitute a uniquely defined and consistent theory of quantum gravity.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188">
        <a href="#cite_note-188">
         [188]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Another approach starts with the
       <a href="/wiki/Canonical_quantization" title="Canonical quantization">
        canonical quantization
       </a>
       procedures of quantum theory. Using the initial-value-formulation of general relativity (cf.
       <a href="/wiki/General_relativity#Evolution_equations" title="General relativity">
        evolution equations
       </a>
       above), the result is the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wheeler%E2%80%93deWitt_equation" title="Wheeler–deWitt equation">
        Wheeler–deWitt equation
       </a>
       (an analogue of the
       <a href="/wiki/Schr%C3%B6dinger_equation" title="Schrödinger equation">
        Schrödinger equation
       </a>
       ) which, regrettably, turns out to be ill-defined without a proper ultraviolet (lattice) cutoff.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189">
        <a href="#cite_note-189">
         [189]
        </a>
       </sup>
       However, with the introduction of what are now known as
       <a href="/wiki/Ashtekar_variables" title="Ashtekar variables">
        Ashtekar variables
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190">
        <a href="#cite_note-190">
         [190]
        </a>
       </sup>
       this leads to a promising model known as
       <a href="/wiki/Loop_quantum_gravity" title="Loop quantum gravity">
        loop quantum gravity
       </a>
       . Space is represented by a web-like structure called a
       <a href="/wiki/Spin_network" title="Spin network">
        spin network
       </a>
       , evolving over time in discrete steps.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191">
        <a href="#cite_note-191">
         [191]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Depending on which features of general relativity and quantum theory are accepted unchanged, and on what level changes are introduced,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-192">
        <a href="#cite_note-192">
         [192]
        </a>
       </sup>
       there are numerous other attempts to arrive at a viable theory of quantum gravity, some examples being the lattice theory of gravity based on the Feynman
       <a href="/wiki/Path_integral_formulation" title="Path integral formulation">
        Path Integral
       </a>
       approach and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Regge_Calculus" title="Regge Calculus">
        Regge Calculus
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hamber_2009_179-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Hamber_2009-179">
         [179]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dynamical_triangulation" title="Dynamical triangulation">
        dynamical triangulations
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193">
        <a href="#cite_note-193">
         [193]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Causal_sets" title="Causal sets">
        causal sets
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194">
        <a href="#cite_note-194">
         [194]
        </a>
       </sup>
       twistor models
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195">
        <a href="#cite_note-195">
         [195]
        </a>
       </sup>
       or the path integral based models of
       <a href="/wiki/Quantum_cosmology" title="Quantum cosmology">
        quantum cosmology
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196">
        <a href="#cite_note-196">
         [196]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       All candidate theories still have major formal and conceptual problems to overcome. They also face the common problem that, as yet, there is no way to put quantum gravity predictions to experimental tests (and thus to decide between the candidates where their predictions vary), although there is hope for this to change as future data from cosmological observations and particle physics experiments becomes available.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197">
        <a href="#cite_note-197">
         [197]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Current_status">
        Current status
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=General_relativity&amp;action=edit&amp;section=33" title="Edit section: Current status">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:LIGO_measurement_of_gravitational_waves.svg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="422" data-file-width="499" height="186" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/LIGO_measurement_of_gravitational_waves.svg/220px-LIGO_measurement_of_gravitational_waves.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/LIGO_measurement_of_gravitational_waves.svg/330px-LIGO_measurement_of_gravitational_waves.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/LIGO_measurement_of_gravitational_waves.svg/440px-LIGO_measurement_of_gravitational_waves.svg.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:LIGO_measurement_of_gravitational_waves.svg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Observation of gravitational waves from binary black hole merger GW150914.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       General relativity has emerged as a highly successful model of gravitation and cosmology, which has so far passed many unambiguous observational and experimental tests. However, there are strong indications the theory is incomplete.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-198">
        <a href="#cite_note-198">
         [198]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The problem of quantum gravity and the question of the reality of spacetime singularities remain open.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-199">
        <a href="#cite_note-199">
         [199]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Observational data that is taken as evidence for dark energy and dark matter could indicate the need for new physics.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-200">
        <a href="#cite_note-200">
         [200]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Even taken as is, general relativity is rich with possibilities for further exploration. Mathematical relativists seek to understand the nature of singularities and the fundamental properties of Einstein's equations,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201">
        <a href="#cite_note-201">
         [201]
        </a>
       </sup>
       while numerical relativists run increasingly powerful computer simulations (such as those describing merging black holes).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202">
        <a href="#cite_note-202">
         [202]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In February 2016, it was announced that the existence of gravitational waves was directly detected by the Advanced LIGO team on September 14, 2015.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NSF_73-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-NSF-73">
         [73]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203">
        <a href="#cite_note-203">
         [203]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204">
        <a href="#cite_note-204">
         [204]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A century after its introduction, general relativity remains a highly active area of research.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205">
        <a href="#cite_note-205">
         [205]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>

      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">
        Notes
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=General_relativity&amp;action=edit&amp;section=35" title="Edit section: Notes">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>

         <span class="reference-text">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Wikiquote-logo.svg">
           <img alt="" class="noviewer" data-file-height="355" data-file-width="300" height="16" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Wikiquote-logo.svg/13px-Wikiquote-logo.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Wikiquote-logo.svg/20px-Wikiquote-logo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Wikiquote-logo.svg/27px-Wikiquote-logo.svg.png 2x" width="13"/>

        <li id="cite_note-5">

           </a>
          </b>
         </span>

           Pais 1982
          </a>

          <a href="#CITEREFJanssen2005">
           Janssen 2005
          </a>
          ; an up-to-date collection of current research, including reprints of many of the original articles, is
          <a href="#CITEREFRenn2007">
           Renn 2007
          </a>
          ; an accessible overview can be found in
          <a href="#CITEREFRenn2005">
           Renn 2005
          </a>
          , pp. 110ff. Einstein's original papers are found in
          <a class="external text" href="http://einsteinpapers.press.princeton.edu/" rel="nofollow">
           Digital Einstein
          </a>
          , volumes 4 and 6. An early key article is
          <a href="#CITEREFEinstein1907">
           Einstein 1907
          </a>
          , cf.
          <a href="#CITEREFPais1982">
           Pais 1982
          </a>
          , ch. 9. The publication featuring the field equations is
          <a href="#CITEREFEinstein1915">
           Einstein 1915
          </a>
          , cf.
          <a href="#CITEREFPais1982">
           Pais 1982
          </a>
          , ch. 11–15
         </span>

           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          Good introductions are, in order of increasing presupposed knowledge of mathematics,
          <a href="#CITEREFGiulini2005">
           Giulini 2005
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#CITEREFMermin2005">
           Mermin 2005
          </a>

          </a>

          </a>

        <li id="cite_note-26">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">

          , sec. 22,
          <a href="#CITEREFSynge1972">
           Synge 1972
          </a>
          , ch. 1 and 2
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-27">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-27">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFEhlers1973">
           Ehlers 1973
          </a>
          , sec. 2.3
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-28">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-28">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFEhlers1973">
           Ehlers 1973
          </a>
          , sec. 1.4,
          <a href="#CITEREFSchutz1985">
           Schutz 1985
          </a>
          , sec. 5.1
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-29">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-29">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFEhlers1973">
           Ehlers 1973
          </a>
          , pp. 17ff; a derivation can be found in
          <a href="#CITEREFMermin2005">
           Mermin 2005
          </a>
          , ch. 12. For the experimental evidence, cf. the section
          <a href="/wiki/General_relativity#Gravitational_time_dilation_and_frequency_shift" title="General relativity">
           Gravitational time dilation and frequency shift
          </a>
          , below
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-30">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-30">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFRindler2001">
           Rindler 2001
          </a>
          , sec. 1.13; for an elementary account, see
          <a href="#CITEREFWheeler1990">
           Wheeler 1990
          </a>
          , ch. 2; there are, however, some differences between the modern version and Einstein's original concept used in the historical derivation of general relativity, cf.
          <a href="#CITEREFNorton1985">
           Norton 1985
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-31">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-31">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFEhlers1973">
           Ehlers 1973
          </a>
          , sec. 1.4 for the experimental evidence, see once more section
          <a href="/wiki/General_relativity#Gravitational_time_dilation_and_frequency_shift" title="General relativity">
           Gravitational time dilation and frequency shift
          </a>
          . Choosing a different connection with non-zero
          <a href="/wiki/Torsion_tensor" title="Torsion tensor">
           torsion
          </a>
          leads to a modified theory known as
          <a href="/wiki/Einstein%E2%80%93Cartan_theory" title="Einstein–Cartan theory">
           Einstein–Cartan theory
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-32">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-32">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFEhlers1973">
           Ehlers 1973
          </a>
          , p. 16,
          <a href="#CITEREFKenyon1990">
           Kenyon 1990
          </a>
          , sec. 7.2,
          <a href="#CITEREFWeinberg1972">
           Weinberg 1972
          </a>
          , sec. 2.8
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-33">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-33">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFEhlers1973">
           Ehlers 1973
          </a>
          , pp. 19–22; for similar derivations, see sections 1 and 2 of ch. 7 in
          <a href="#CITEREFWeinberg1972">
           Weinberg 1972
          </a>
          . The Einstein tensor is the only divergence-free tensor that is a function of the metric coefficients, their first and second derivatives at most, and allows the spacetime of special relativity as a solution in the absence of sources of gravity, cf.
          <a href="#CITEREFLovelock1972">
           Lovelock 1972
          </a>
          . The tensors on both side are of second rank, that is, they can each be thought of as 4×4 matrices, each of which contains ten independent terms; hence, the above represents ten coupled equations. The fact that, as a consequence of geometric relations known as
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bianchi_identities" title="Bianchi identities">
           Bianchi identities
          </a>
          , the Einstein tensor satisfies a further four identities reduces these to six independent equations, e.g.
          <a href="#CITEREFSchutz1985">
           Schutz 1985
          </a>
          , sec. 8.3
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-34">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-34">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFKenyon1990">
           Kenyon 1990
          </a>
          , sec. 7.4
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-35">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-35">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFBransDicke1961">
           Brans &amp; Dicke 1961
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#CITEREFWeinberg1972">
           Weinberg 1972
          </a>
          , sec. 3 in ch. 7,
          <a href="#CITEREFGoenner2004">
           Goenner 2004
          </a>
          , sec. 7.2, and
          <a href="#CITEREFTrautman2006">
           Trautman 2006
          </a>
          , respectively
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-36">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-36">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>

          <a href="#CITEREFWeinberg1972">

          </a>
          , ch. 7 or, in fact, any other textbook on general relativity
         </span>

        <li id="cite_note-53">

        <li id="cite_note-54">

        <li id="cite_note-55">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">

         </span>

        <li id="cite_note-56">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">

         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-57">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-57">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">

          <a href="/wiki/Hafele%E2%80%93Keating_experiment" title="Hafele–Keating experiment">
           Hafele–Keating experiment
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#CITEREFHafeleKeating1972a">

          </a>
          and
          <a href="#CITEREFHafeleKeating1972b">

          </a>
          , and culminating in the
          <a href="/wiki/Gravity_Probe_A" title="Gravity Probe A">
           Gravity Probe A
          </a>
          experiment; an overview of experiments can be found in
          <a href="#CITEREFOhanianRuffini1994">
           Ohanian &amp; Ruffini 1994
          </a>
          , table 4.1 on p. 186
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-58">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-58">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          GPS is continually tested by comparing atomic clocks on the ground and aboard orbiting satellites; for an account of relativistic effects, see
          <a href="#CITEREFAshby2002">
           Ashby 2002
          </a>
          and
          <a href="#CITEREFAshby2003">
           Ashby 2003
          </a>
         </span>

        <li id="cite_note-59">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">

        <li id="cite_note-60">

        <li id="cite_note-61">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-61">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFOhanianRuffini1994">
           Ohanian &amp; Ruffini 1994
          </a>
          , pp. 164–172
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-62">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-62">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          Cf.
          <a href="#CITEREFKennefick2005">
           Kennefick 2005
          </a>
          for the classic early measurements by Arthur Eddington's expeditions. For an overview of more recent measurements, see
          <a href="#CITEREFOhanianRuffini1994">
           Ohanian &amp; Ruffini 1994
          </a>
          , ch. 4.3. For the most precise direct modern observations using quasars, cf.
          <a href="#CITEREFShapiroDavisLebachGregory2004">
           Shapiro et al. 2004
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-63">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-63">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          This is not an independent axiom; it can be derived from Einstein's equations and the Maxwell
          <a href="/wiki/Lagrangian_(field_theory)" title="Lagrangian (field theory)">
           Lagrangian
          </a>
          using a
          <a href="/wiki/WKB_approximation" title="WKB approximation">
           WKB approximation
          </a>
          , cf.
          <a href="#CITEREFEhlers1973">
           Ehlers 1973
          </a>
          , sec. 5
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-64">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-64">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFBlanchet2006">
           Blanchet 2006
          </a>
          , sec. 1.3
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-65">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-65">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFRindler2001">
           Rindler 2001
          </a>
          , sec. 1.16; for the historical examples,
          <a href="#CITEREFIsrael1987">
           Israel 1987
          </a>
          , pp. 202–204; in fact, Einstein published one such derivation as
          <a href="#CITEREFEinstein1907">
           Einstein 1907
          </a>
          . Such calculations tacitly assume that the geometry of space is
          <a href="/wiki/Euclidean_space" title="Euclidean space">
           Euclidean
          </a>
          , cf.
          <a href="#CITEREFEhlersRindler1997">
           Ehlers &amp; Rindler 1997
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-66">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-66">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          From the standpoint of Einstein's theory, these derivations take into account the effect of gravity on time, but not its consequences for the warping of space, cf.
          <a href="#CITEREFRindler2001">
           Rindler 2001
          </a>
          , sec. 11.11
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-67">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-67">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          For the Sun's gravitational field using radar signals reflected from planets such as
          <a href="/wiki/Venus" title="Venus">
           Venus
          </a>
          and Mercury, cf.
          <a href="#CITEREFShapiro1964">
           Shapiro 1964
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#CITEREFWeinberg1972">
           Weinberg 1972
          </a>
          , ch. 8, sec. 7; for signals actively sent back by space probes (
          <a href="/wiki/Transponder" title="Transponder">
           transponder
          </a>
          measurements), cf.
          <a href="#CITEREFBertottiIessTortora2003">
           Bertotti, Iess &amp; Tortora 2003
          </a>
          ; for an overview, see
          <a href="#CITEREFOhanianRuffini1994">
           Ohanian &amp; Ruffini 1994
          </a>
          , table 4.4 on p. 200; for more recent measurements using signals received from a
          <a href="/wiki/Pulsar" title="Pulsar">
           pulsar
          </a>
          that is part of a binary system, the gravitational field causing the time delay being that of the other pulsar, cf.
          <a href="#CITEREFStairs2003">
           Stairs 2003
          </a>
          , sec. 4.4
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-68">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-68">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFWill1993">

          , sec. 7.1 and 7.2
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-69">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-69">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation journal">
           Einstein, A (June 1916).
           <a class="external text" href="http://einstein-annalen.mpiwg-berlin.mpg.de/related_texts/sitzungsberichte" rel="nofollow">
            "Näherungsweise Integration der Feldgleichungen der Gravitation"
           </a>
           .
           <i>
            <a href="/wiki/Prussian_Academy_of_Sciences" title="Prussian Academy of Sciences">
             Sitzungsberichte der Königlich Preussischen Akademie der Wissenschaften Berlin
            </a>
           </i>
           . part 1: 688–696.
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Sitzungsberichte+der+K%C3%B6niglich+Preussischen+Akademie+der+Wissenschaften+Berlin&amp;rft.atitle=N%C3%A4herungsweise+Integration+der+Feldgleichungen+der+Gravitation&amp;rft.volume=part+1&amp;rft.pages=688-696&amp;rft.date=1916-06&amp;rft.au=Einstein%2C+A&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Feinstein-annalen.mpiwg-berlin.mpg.de%2Frelated_texts%2Fsitzungsberichte&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AGeneral+relativity">

        <li id="cite_note-70">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-70">
            ^

         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation journal">
           Einstein, A (1918).
           <a class="external text" href="http://einstein-annalen.mpiwg-berlin.mpg.de/related_texts/sitzungsberichte" rel="nofollow">
            "Über Gravitationswellen"
           </a>
           .
           <i>
            Sitzungsberichte der Königlich Preussischen Akademie der Wissenschaften Berlin
           </i>
           . part 1: 154–167.

          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Sitzungsberichte+der+K%C3%B6niglich+Preussischen+Akademie+der+Wissenschaften+Berlin&amp;rft.atitle=%C3%9Cber+Gravitationswellen&amp;rft.volume=part+1&amp;rft.pages=154-167&amp;rft.date=1918&amp;rft.au=Einstein%2C+A&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Feinstein-annalen.mpiwg-berlin.mpg.de%2Frelated_texts%2Fsitzungsberichte&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AGeneral+relativity">

         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">

         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation journal">
           Castelvecchi, Davide; Witze, Witze (February 11, 2016).
           <a class="external text" href="http://www.nature.com/news/einstein-s-gravitational-waves-found-at-last-1.19361" rel="nofollow">
            "Einstein's gravitational waves found at last"

          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Nature+News&amp;rft.atitle=Einstein%27s+gravitational+waves+found+at+last&amp;rft.date=2016-02-11&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1038%2Fnature.2016.19361&amp;rft.aulast=Castelvecchi&amp;rft.aufirst=Davide&amp;rft.au=Witze%2C+Witze&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nature.com%2Fnews%2Feinstein-s-gravitational-waves-found-at-last-1.19361&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AGeneral+relativity">

        <li id="cite_note-Abbot-72">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          ^
          <a href="#cite_ref-Abbot_72-0">
           <sup>
            <i>
             <b>
              a
             </b>
            </i>
           </sup>
          </a>
          <a href="#cite_ref-Abbot_72-1">
           <sup>
            <i>
             <b>

            </i>

          </a>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation journal">
           B. P. Abbott; et al. (LIGO Scientific Collaboration and Virgo Collaboration) (2016).
           <a class="external text" href="https://journals.aps.org/prl/abstract/10.1103/PhysRevLett.116.061102" rel="nofollow">
            "Observation of Gravitational Waves from a Binary Black Hole Merger"
           </a>
           .
           <i>
            Physical Review Letters
           </i>
           .
           <b>
            116
           </b>
           (6): 061102.
           <a href="/wiki/ArXiv" title="ArXiv">

           </a>
           :
           <span class="plainlinks">
            <a class="external text" href="//arxiv.org/abs/1602.03837" rel="nofollow">
             1602.03837
            </a>
            <img alt="Freely accessible" data-file-height="813" data-file-width="512" height="14" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Lock-green.svg/9px-Lock-green.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Lock-green.svg/14px-Lock-green.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Lock-green.svg/18px-Lock-green.svg.png 2x" title="Freely accessible" width="9"/>
           </span>
           .
           <a href="/wiki/Bibcode" title="Bibcode">
            Bibcode
           </a>
           :
           <a class="external text" href="http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2016PhRvL.116f1102A" rel="nofollow">
            2016PhRvL.116f1102A

            doi

          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Physical+Review+Letters&amp;rft.atitle=Observation+of+Gravitational+Waves+from+a+Binary+Black+Hole+Merger&amp;rft.volume=116&amp;rft.issue=6&amp;rft.pages=061102&amp;rft.date=2016&amp;rft_id=info%3Aarxiv%2F1602.03837&amp;rft_id=info%3Apmid%2F26918975&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1103%2FPhysRevLett.116.061102&amp;rft_id=info%3Abibcode%2F2016PhRvL.116f1102A&amp;rft.au=B.%E2%80%89P.+Abbott&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fjournals.aps.org%2Fprl%2Fabstract%2F10.1103%2FPhysRevLett.116.061102&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AGeneral+relativity">

        <li id="cite_note-NSF-73">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          ^
          <a href="#cite_ref-NSF_73-0">
           <sup>
            <i>
             <b>
              a
             </b>
            </i>
           </sup>
          </a>
          <a href="#cite_ref-NSF_73-1">

             </b>
            </i>
           </sup>
          </a>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation web">
           <a class="external text" href="http://www.nsf.gov/news/news_summ.jsp?cntn_id=137628" rel="nofollow">
            "Gravitational waves detected 100 years after Einstein's prediction | NSF - National Science Foundation"
           </a>
           .
           <i>
            www.nsf.gov
           </i>
           <span class="reference-accessdate">

          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=www.nsf.gov&amp;rft.atitle=Gravitational+waves+detected+100+years+after+Einstein%27s+prediction+%7C+NSF+-+National+Science+Foundation&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nsf.gov%2Fnews%2Fnews_summ.jsp%3Fcntn_id%3D137628&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AGeneral+relativity">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-74">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-74">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          Most advanced textbooks on general relativity contain a description of these properties, e.g.
          <a href="#CITEREFSchutz1985">
           Schutz 1985
          </a>
          , ch. 9
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-75">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-75">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          For example
          <a href="#CITEREFJaranowskiKrólak2005">
           Jaranowski &amp; Królak 2005
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-76">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-76">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFRindler2001">
           Rindler 2001
          </a>
          , ch. 13
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-77">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-77">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFGowdy1971">
           Gowdy 1971
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#CITEREFGowdy1974">
           Gowdy 1974
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-78">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-78">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          See
          <a href="#CITEREFLehner2002">
           Lehner 2002
          </a>
          for a brief introduction to the methods of numerical relativity, and
          <a href="#CITEREFSeidel1998">
           Seidel 1998
          </a>
          for the connection with gravitational wave astronomy
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-79">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-79">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFSchutz2003">
           Schutz 2003
          </a>
          , pp. 48–49,
          <a href="#CITEREFPais1982">
           Pais 1982
          </a>
          , pp. 253–254
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-80">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-80">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFRindler2001">
           Rindler 2001
          </a>
          , sec. 11.9
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-81">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-81">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFWill1993">
           Will 1993
          </a>
          , pp. 177–181
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-82">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-82">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          In consequence, in the parameterized post-Newtonian formalism (PPN), measurements of this effect determine a linear combination of the terms β and γ, cf.
          <a href="#CITEREFWill2006">
           Will 2006
          </a>
          , sec. 3.5 and
          <a href="#CITEREFWill1993">
           Will 1993
          </a>
          , sec. 7.3
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-83">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-83">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          The most precise measurements are
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/VLBI" title="VLBI">
           VLBI
          </a>
          measurements of planetary positions; see
          <a href="#CITEREFWill1993">
           Will 1993
          </a>
          , ch. 5,
          <a href="#CITEREFWill2006">
           Will 2006
          </a>
          , sec. 3.5,
          <a href="#CITEREFAndersonCampbellJurgensLau1992">
           Anderson et al. 1992
          </a>
          ; for an overview,
          <a href="#CITEREFOhanianRuffini1994">
           Ohanian &amp; Ruffini 1994
          </a>
          , pp. 406–407
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-84">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-84">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">

          </a>

          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-98">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation" id="CITEREFIorio_L.2006">
           Iorio L. (August 2006), "COMMENTS, REPLIES AND NOTES: A note on the evidence of the gravitomagnetic field of Mars",

        <li id="cite_note-113">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-113">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation web">
           <a class="external text" href="http://www.nsf.gov/news/news_summ.jsp?cntn_id=137628" rel="nofollow">
            "Gravitational waves detected 100 years after Einstein's prediction | NSF – National Science Foundation"
           </a>
           .
           <i>
            www.nsf.gov
           </i>
           <span class="reference-accessdate">
            . Retrieved
            <span class="nowrap">
             2016-02-11
            </span>
           </span>
           .
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=www.nsf.gov&amp;rft.atitle=Gravitational+waves+detected+100+years+after+Einstein%27s+prediction+%7C+NSF+%E2%80%93+National+Science+Foundation&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nsf.gov%2Fnews%2Fnews_summ.jsp%3Fcntn_id%3D137628&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AGeneral+relativity">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-114">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-114">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFMiller2002">
           Miller 2002
          </a>
          , lectures 19 and 21
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-115">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-115">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFCelottiMillerSciama1999">
           Celotti, Miller &amp; Sciama 1999
          </a>
          , sec. 3
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-116">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-116">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFSpringelWhiteJenkinsFrenk2005">
           Springel et al. 2005
          </a>
          and the accompanying summary
          <a href="#CITEREFGnedin2005">
           Gnedin 2005
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-117">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-117">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFBlandford1987">
           Blandford 1987
          </a>
          , sec. 8.2.4
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-118">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-118">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          For the basic mechanism, see
          <a href="#CITEREFCarrollOstlie1996">
           Carroll &amp; Ostlie 1996
          </a>
          , sec. 17.2; for more about the different types of astronomical objects associated with this, cf.
          <a href="#CITEREFRobson1996">
           Robson 1996
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-119">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-119">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          For a review, see
          <a href="#CITEREFBegelmanBlandfordRees1984">
           Begelman, Blandford &amp; Rees 1984
          </a>
          . To a distant observer, some of these jets even appear to move
          <a href="/wiki/Superluminal_motion" title="Superluminal motion">
           faster than light
          </a>
          ; this, however, can be explained as an optical illusion that does not violate the tenets of relativity, see
          <a href="#CITEREFRees1966">
           Rees 1966
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-120">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-120">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          For stellar end states, cf.
          <a href="#CITEREFOppenheimerSnyder1939">
           Oppenheimer &amp; Snyder 1939
          </a>
          or, for more recent numerical work,
          <a href="#CITEREFFont2003">
           Font 2003
          </a>
          , sec. 4.1; for supernovae, there are still major problems to be solved, cf.
          <a href="#CITEREFBurasRamppJankaKifonidis2003">
           Buras et al. 2003
          </a>
          ; for simulating accretion and the formation of jets, cf.
          <a href="#CITEREFFont2003">
           Font 2003
          </a>
          , sec. 4.2. Also, relativistic lensing effects are thought to play a role for the signals received from
          <a href="/wiki/X-ray_pulsar" title="X-ray pulsar">
           X-ray pulsars
          </a>
          , cf.
          <a href="#CITEREFKraus1998">
           Kraus 1998
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-121">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-121">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          The evidence includes limits on compactness from the observation of accretion-driven phenomena ("
          <a href="/wiki/Eddington_luminosity" title="Eddington luminosity">
           Eddington luminosity
          </a>
          "), see
          <a href="#CITEREFCelottiMillerSciama1999">
           Celotti, Miller &amp; Sciama 1999
          </a>
          , observations of stellar dynamics in the center of our own
          <a href="/wiki/Milky_Way" title="Milky Way">
           Milky Way
          </a>
          galaxy, cf.
          <a href="#CITEREFSchödelOttGenzelEckart2003">
           Schödel et al. 2003
          </a>
          , and indications that at least some of the compact objects in question appear to have no solid surface, which can be deduced from the examination of
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/X-ray_burst" title="X-ray burst">
           X-ray bursts
          </a>
          for which the central compact object is either a neutron star or a black hole; cf.
          <a href="#CITEREFRemillardLinCooperNarayan2006">
           Remillard et al. 2006
          </a>
          for an overview,
          <a href="#CITEREFNarayan2006">
           Narayan 2006
          </a>
          , sec. 5. Observations of the "shadow" of the Milky Way galaxy's central black hole horizon are eagerly sought for, cf.
          <a href="#CITEREFFalckeMeliaAgol2000">
           Falcke, Melia &amp; Agol 2000
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-122">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-122">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFDalalHolzHughesJain2006">
           Dalal et al. 2006
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-123">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-123">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFBarackCutler2004">
           Barack &amp; Cutler 2004
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-124">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-124">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          Originally
          <a href="#CITEREFEinstein1917">
           Einstein 1917
          </a>
          ; cf.
          <a href="#CITEREFPais1982">
           Pais 1982
          </a>
          , pp. 285–288
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-125">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-125">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFCarroll2001">
           Carroll 2001
          </a>
          , ch. 2
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-126">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-126">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFBergströmGoobar2003">
           Bergström &amp; Goobar 2003
          </a>
          , ch. 9–11; use of these models is justified by the fact that, at large scales of around hundred million
          <a href="/wiki/Light-year" title="Light-year">
           light-years
          </a>
          and more, our own universe indeed appears to be isotropic and homogeneous, cf.
          <a href="#CITEREFPeeblesSchrammTurnerKron1991">
           Peebles et al. 1991
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-127">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-127">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          E.g. with
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/WMAP" title="WMAP">
           WMAP
          </a>
          data, see
          <a href="#CITEREFSpergelVerdePeirisKomatsu2003">
           Spergel et al. 2003
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-128">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-128">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          These tests involve the separate observations detailed further on, see, e.g., fig. 2 in
          <a href="#CITEREFBridleLahavOstrikerSteinhardt2003">
           Bridle et al. 2003
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-129">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-129">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFPeebles1966">
           Peebles 1966
          </a>
          ; for a recent account of predictions, see
          <a href="#CITEREFCoc,_Vangioni‐Flam_et_al.2004">
           Coc, Vangioni‐Flam et al. 2004
          </a>
          ; an accessible account can be found in
          <a href="#CITEREFWeiss2006">
           Weiss 2006
          </a>
          ; compare with the observations in
          <a href="#CITEREFOliveSkillman2004">
           Olive &amp; Skillman 2004
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#CITEREFBaniaRoodBalser2002">
           Bania, Rood &amp; Balser 2002
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#CITEREFO'MearaTytlerKirkmanSuzuki2001">
           O'Meara et al. 2001
          </a>
          , and
          <a href="#CITEREFCharbonnelPrimas2005">
           Charbonnel &amp; Primas 2005
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-130">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-130">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFLahavSuto2004">
           Lahav &amp; Suto 2004
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#CITEREFBertschinger1998">
           Bertschinger 1998
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#CITEREFSpringelWhiteJenkinsFrenk2005">
           Springel et al. 2005
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-131">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-131">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFAlpherHerman1948">
           Alpher &amp; Herman 1948
          </a>
          , for a pedagogical introduction, see
          <a href="#CITEREFBergströmGoobar2003">
           Bergström &amp; Goobar 2003
          </a>
          , ch. 11; for the initial detection, see
          <a href="#CITEREFPenziasWilson1965">
           Penzias &amp; Wilson 1965
          </a>
          and, for precision measurements by satellite observatories,
          <a href="#CITEREFMatherChengCottinghamEplee1994">
           Mather et al. 1994
          </a>
          (
          <a href="/wiki/Cosmic_Background_Explorer" title="Cosmic Background Explorer">
           COBE
          </a>
          ) and
          <a href="#CITEREFBennettHalpernHinshawJarosik2003">
           Bennett et al. 2003
          </a>
          (WMAP). Future measurements could also reveal evidence about gravitational waves in the early universe; this additional information is contained in the background radiation's
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Polarized_light" title="Polarized light">
           polarization
          </a>
          , cf.
          <a href="#CITEREFKamionkowskiKosowskyStebbins1997">
           Kamionkowski, Kosowsky &amp; Stebbins 1997
          </a>
          and
          <a href="#CITEREFSeljakZaldarriaga1997">
           Seljak &amp; Zaldarriaga 1997
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-132">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-132">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          Evidence for this comes from the determination of cosmological parameters and additional observations involving the dynamics of galaxies and galaxy clusters cf.
          <a href="#CITEREFPeebles1993">
           Peebles 1993
          </a>
          , ch. 18, evidence from gravitational lensing, cf.
          <a href="#CITEREFPeacock1999">
           Peacock 1999
          </a>
          , sec. 4.6, and simulations of large-scale structure formation, see
          <a href="#CITEREFSpringelWhiteJenkinsFrenk2005">
           Springel et al. 2005
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-133">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-133">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFPeacock1999">
           Peacock 1999
          </a>
          , ch. 12,
          <a href="#CITEREFPeskin2007">
           Peskin 2007
          </a>
          ; in particular, observations indicate that all but a negligible portion of that matter is not in the form of the usual
          <a href="/wiki/Elementary_particle" title="Elementary particle">
           elementary particles
          </a>
          ("non-
          <a href="/wiki/Baryon" title="Baryon">
           baryonic
          </a>
          matter"), cf.
          <a href="#CITEREFPeacock1999">
           Peacock 1999
          </a>
          , ch. 12
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-134">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-134">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          Namely, some physicists have questioned whether or not the evidence for dark matter is, in fact, evidence for deviations from the Einsteinian (and the Newtonian) description of gravity cf. the overview in
          <a href="#CITEREFMannheim2006">
           Mannheim 2006
          </a>
          , sec. 9
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-135">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-135">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFCarroll2001">
           Carroll 2001
          </a>
          ; an accessible overview is given in
          <a href="#CITEREFCaldwell2004">
           Caldwell 2004
          </a>
          . Here, too, scientists have argued that the evidence indicates not a new form of energy, but the need for modifications in our cosmological models, cf.
          <a href="#CITEREFMannheim2006">
           Mannheim 2006
          </a>
          , sec. 10; aforementioned modifications need not be modifications of general relativity, they could, for example, be modifications in the way we treat the inhomogeneities in the universe, cf.
          <a href="#CITEREFBuchert2007">
           Buchert 2007
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-136">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-136">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          A good introduction is
          <a href="#CITEREFLinde1990">
           Linde 1990
          </a>
          ; for a more recent review, see
          <a href="#CITEREFLinde2005">
           Linde 2005
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-137">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-137">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          More precisely, these are the
          <a href="/wiki/Flatness_problem" title="Flatness problem">
           flatness problem
          </a>
          , the
          <a href="/wiki/Horizon_problem" title="Horizon problem">
           horizon problem
          </a>
          , and the
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Monopole_problem" title="Monopole problem">
           monopole problem
          </a>
          ; a pedagogical introduction can be found in
          <a href="#CITEREFNarlikar1993">
           Narlikar 1993
          </a>
          , sec. 6.4, see also
          <a href="#CITEREFBörner1993">
           Börner 1993
          </a>
          , sec. 9.1
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-138">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-138">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFSpergelBeanDoréNolta2007">
           Spergel et al. 2007
          </a>
          , sec. 5,6
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-139">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-139">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          More concretely, the
          <a href="/wiki/Potential" title="Potential">
           potential
          </a>
          function that is crucial to determining the dynamics of the
          <a href="/wiki/Inflaton" title="Inflaton">
           inflaton
          </a>
          is simply postulated, but not derived from an underlying physical theory
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-140">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-140">
            ^
           </a>

         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFBrandenberger2007">

          </a>

         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-141">
