            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFGödel1949">
           Gödel 1949
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-142">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-142">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">

          <a href="#CITEREFWald1984">

          <a href="#CITEREFHawkingEllis1973">

        <li id="cite_note-143">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-143">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFWald1984">
           Wald 1984
          </a>
          , sec. 9.2–9.4 and
          <a href="#CITEREFHawkingEllis1973">
           Hawking &amp; Ellis 1973
          </a>
          , ch. 6
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-144">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-144">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFThorne1972">
           Thorne 1972
          </a>
          ; for more recent numerical studies, see
          <a href="#CITEREFBerger2002">
           Berger 2002
          </a>
          , sec. 2.1
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-145">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-145">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFIsrael1987">
           Israel 1987
          </a>
          . A more exact mathematical description distinguishes several kinds of horizon, notably event horizons and
          <a href="/wiki/Apparent_horizon" title="Apparent horizon">
           apparent horizons
          </a>
          cf.
          <a href="#CITEREFHawkingEllis1973">
           Hawking &amp; Ellis 1973
          </a>
          , pp. 312–320 or
          <a href="#CITEREFWald1984">
           Wald 1984
          </a>
          , sec. 12.2; there are also more intuitive definitions for isolated systems that do not require knowledge of spacetime properties at infinity, cf.
          <a href="#CITEREFAshtekarKrishnan2004">
           Ashtekar &amp; Krishnan 2004
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-146">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-146">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          For first steps, cf.
          <a href="#CITEREFIsrael1971">
           Israel 1971
          </a>
          ; see
          <a href="#CITEREFHawkingEllis1973">
           Hawking &amp; Ellis 1973
          </a>
          , sec. 9.3 or
          <a href="#CITEREFHeusler1996">
           Heusler 1996
          </a>
          , ch. 9 and 10 for a derivation, and
          <a href="#CITEREFHeusler1998">
           Heusler 1998
          </a>
          as well as
          <a href="#CITEREFBeigChruściel2006">
           Beig &amp; Chruściel 2006
          </a>
          as overviews of more recent results
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-147">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-147">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          The laws of black hole mechanics were first described in
          <a href="#CITEREFBardeenCarterHawking1973">
           Bardeen, Carter &amp; Hawking 1973
          </a>
          ; a more pedagogical presentation can be found in
          <a href="#CITEREFCarter1979">
           Carter 1979
          </a>
          ; for a more recent review, see
          <a href="#CITEREFWald2001">
           Wald 2001
          </a>
          , ch. 2. A thorough, book-length introduction including an introduction to the necessary mathematics
          <a href="#CITEREFPoisson2004">
           Poisson 2004
          </a>
          . For the Penrose process, see
          <a href="#CITEREFPenrose1969">
           Penrose 1969
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-148">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-148">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFBekenstein1973">
           Bekenstein 1973
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#CITEREFBekenstein1974">
           Bekenstein 1974
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-149">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-149">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          The fact that black holes radiate, quantum mechanically, was first derived in
          <a href="#CITEREFHawking1975">
           Hawking 1975
          </a>
          ; a more thorough derivation can be found in
          <a href="#CITEREFWald1975">
           Wald 1975
          </a>
          . A review is given in
          <a href="#CITEREFWald2001">
           Wald 2001
          </a>
          , ch. 3
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-150">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">

        <li id="cite_note-151">

        <li id="cite_note-152">

        <li id="cite_note-153">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-153">

           </a>

         </span>

        <li id="cite_note-154">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">

        <li id="cite_note-155">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-155">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFEllisVan_Elst1999">
           Ellis &amp; Van Elst 1999
          </a>
          ; a closer look at the singularity itself is taken in
          <a href="#CITEREFBörner1993">
           Börner 1993
          </a>
          , sec. 1.2
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-156">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-156">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          Here one should remind to the well-known fact that the important "quasi-optical" singularities of the so-called
          <a href="/wiki/Eikonal_approximation" title="Eikonal approximation">
           eikonal approximations
          </a>
          of many wave-equations, namely the "
          <a href="/wiki/Caustic_(mathematics)" title="Caustic (mathematics)">
           caustics
          </a>
          ", are resolved into finite peaks beyond that approximation.
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-157">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-157">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          Namely when there are
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trapped_null_surface" title="Trapped null surface">
           trapped null surfaces
          </a>
          , cf.
          <a href="#CITEREFPenrose1965">
           Penrose 1965
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-158">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-158">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFHawking1966">
           Hawking 1966
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-159">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-159">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          The conjecture was made in
          <a href="#CITEREFBelinskiiKhalatnikovLifschitz1971">
           Belinskii, Khalatnikov &amp; Lifschitz 1971
          </a>
          ; for a more recent review, see
          <a href="#CITEREFBerger2002">
           Berger 2002
          </a>
          . An accessible exposition is given by
          <a href="#CITEREFGarfinkle2007">
           Garfinkle 2007
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-160">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-160">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          The restriction to future singularities naturally excludes initial singularities such as the big bang singularity, which in principle be visible to observers at later cosmic time. The cosmic censorship conjecture was first presented in
          <a href="#CITEREFPenrose1969">
           Penrose 1969
          </a>
          ; a textbook-level account is given in
          <a href="#CITEREFWald1984">
           Wald 1984
          </a>
          , pp. 302–305. For numerical results, see the review
          <a href="#CITEREFBerger2002">
           Berger 2002
          </a>
          , sec. 2.1
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-161">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-161">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFHawkingEllis1973">
           Hawking &amp; Ellis 1973
          </a>
          , sec. 7.1
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-162">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-162">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFArnowittDeserMisner1962">
           Arnowitt, Deser &amp; Misner 1962
          </a>
          ; for a pedagogical introduction, see
          <a href="#CITEREFMisnerThorneWheeler1973">
           Misner, Thorne &amp; Wheeler 1973
          </a>
          , §21.4–§21.7
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-163">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-163">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFFourès-Bruhat1952">
           Fourès-Bruhat 1952
          </a>
          and
          <a href="#CITEREFBruhat1962">
           Bruhat 1962
          </a>
          ; for a pedagogical introduction, see

          </a>
          , ch. 10; an online review can be found in
          <a href="#CITEREFReula1998">

          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-164">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-164">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFGourgoulhon2007">

          </a>
          ; for a review of the basics of numerical relativity, including the problems arising from the peculiarities of Einstein's equations, see
          <a href="#CITEREFLehner2001">
           Lehner 2001
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-165">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-165">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFMisnerThorneWheeler1973">
           Misner, Thorne &amp; Wheeler 1973
          </a>
          , §20.4
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-166">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-166">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFArnowittDeserMisner1962">
           Arnowitt, Deser &amp; Misner 1962
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-167">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-167">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFKomar1959">
           Komar 1959
          </a>
          ; for a pedagogical introduction, see
          <a href="#CITEREFWald1984">
           Wald 1984
          </a>
          , sec. 11.2; although defined in a totally different way, it can be shown to be equivalent to the ADM mass for stationary spacetimes, cf.
          <a href="#CITEREFAshtekarMagnon-Ashtekar1979">
           Ashtekar &amp; Magnon-Ashtekar 1979
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-168">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-168">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          For a pedagogical introduction, see
          <a href="#CITEREFWald1984">
           Wald 1984
          </a>
          , sec. 11.2
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-169">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-169">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFWald1984">
           Wald 1984
          </a>
          , p. 295 and refs therein; this is important for questions of stability—if there were
          <a href="/wiki/Negative_mass" title="Negative mass">
           negative mass
          </a>
          states, then flat, empty Minkowski space, which has mass zero, could evolve into these states
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-170">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-170">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFTownsend1997">
           Townsend 1997
          </a>
          , ch. 5
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-171">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-171">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          Such quasi-local mass–energy definitions are the
          <a href="/wiki/Hawking_energy" title="Hawking energy">
           Hawking energy
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="/wiki/Geroch_energy" title="Geroch energy">
           Geroch energy
          </a>
          , or Penrose's quasi-local energy–momentum based on
          <a href="/wiki/Twistor_theory" title="Twistor theory">
           twistor
          </a>
          methods; cf. the review article
          <a href="#CITEREFSzabados2004">
           Szabados 2004
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-172">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-172">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          An overview of quantum theory can be found in standard textbooks such as
          <a href="#CITEREFMessiah1999">
           Messiah 1999
          </a>
          ; a more elementary account is given in
          <a href="#CITEREFHeyWalters2003">
           Hey &amp; Walters 2003
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-173">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-173">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFRamond1990">
           Ramond 1990
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#CITEREFWeinberg1995">
           Weinberg 1995
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#CITEREFPeskinSchroeder1995">
           Peskin &amp; Schroeder 1995
          </a>
          ; a more accessible overview is
          <a href="#CITEREFAuyang1995">
           Auyang 1995
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-174">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-174">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFWald1994">
           Wald 1994
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#CITEREFBirrellDavies1984">
           Birrell &amp; Davies 1984
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-175">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-175">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          For Hawking radiation
          <a href="#CITEREFHawking1975">
           Hawking 1975
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#CITEREFWald1975">
           Wald 1975
          </a>
          ; an accessible introduction to black hole evaporation can be found in
          <a href="#CITEREFTraschen2000">
           Traschen 2000
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-176">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-176">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFWald2001">
           Wald 2001
          </a>
          , ch. 3
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-177">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-177">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          Put simply, matter is the source of spacetime curvature, and once matter has quantum properties, we can expect spacetime to have them as well. Cf.
          <a href="#CITEREFCarlip2001">
           Carlip 2001
          </a>
          , sec. 2
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-178">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-178">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFSchutz2003">
           Schutz 2003
          </a>
          , p. 407
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-Hamber_2009-179">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          ^
          <a href="#cite_ref-Hamber_2009_179-0">
           <sup>
            <i>
             <b>
              a
             </b>
            </i>
           </sup>
          </a>
          <a href="#cite_ref-Hamber_2009_179-1">
           <sup>
            <i>
             <b>
              b
             </b>
            </i>
           </sup>
          </a>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFHamber2009">
           Hamber 2009
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-180">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-180">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          A timeline and overview can be found in
          <a href="#CITEREFRovelli2000">
           Rovelli 2000
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-181">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-181">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREF't_HooftVeltman1974">
           't Hooft &amp; Veltman 1974
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-182">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-182">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFDonoghue1995">
           Donoghue 1995
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-183">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-183">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          In particular, a perturbative technique known as
          <a href="/wiki/Renormalization" title="Renormalization">
           renormalization
          </a>
          , an integral part of deriving predictions which take into account higher-energy contributions, cf.
          <a href="#CITEREFWeinberg1996">
           Weinberg 1996
          </a>
          , ch. 17, 18, fails in this case; cf.
          <a href="#CITEREFVeltman1975">
           Veltman 1975
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#CITEREFGoroffSagnotti1985">
           Goroff &amp; Sagnotti 1985
          </a>
          ; for a recent comprehensive review of the failure of perturbative renormalizability for quantum gravity see
          <a href="#CITEREFHamber2009">
           Hamber 2009
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-184">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-184">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          An accessible introduction at the undergraduate level can be found in
          <a href="#CITEREFZwiebach2004">
           Zwiebach 2004
          </a>
          ; more complete overviews can be found in
          <a href="#CITEREFPolchinski1998a">
           Polchinski 1998a
          </a>
          and
          <a href="#CITEREFPolchinski1998b">
           Polchinski 1998b
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-185">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-185">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          At the energies reached in current experiments, these strings are indistinguishable from point-like particles, but, crucially, different
          <a href="/wiki/Normal_mode" title="Normal mode">
           modes
          </a>
          of oscillation of one and the same type of fundamental string appear as particles with different (
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Electric" title="Electric">
           electric
          </a>
          and other)
          <a href="/wiki/Charge_(physics)" title="Charge (physics)">
           charges
          </a>
          , e.g.
          <a href="#CITEREFIbanez2000">
           Ibanez 2000
          </a>
          . The theory is successful in that one mode will always correspond to a
          <a href="/wiki/Graviton" title="Graviton">
           graviton
          </a>
          , the
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Messenger_particle" title="Messenger particle">
           messenger particle
          </a>
          of gravity, e.g.
          <a href="#CITEREFGreenSchwarzWitten1987">
           Green, Schwarz &amp; Witten 1987
          </a>
          , sec. 2.3, 5.3
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-186">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-186">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFGreenSchwarzWitten1987">
           Green, Schwarz &amp; Witten 1987
          </a>
          , sec. 4.2
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-187">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-187">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFWeinberg2000">
           Weinberg 2000
          </a>
          , ch. 31
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-188">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-188">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFTownsend1996">
           Townsend 1996
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#CITEREFDuff1996">
           Duff 1996
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-189">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-189">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFKuchař1973">
           Kuchař 1973
          </a>
          , sec. 3
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-190">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-190">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          These variables represent geometric gravity using mathematical analogues of
          <a href="/wiki/Electric_field" title="Electric field">
           electric
          </a>
          and
          <a href="/wiki/Magnetic_field" title="Magnetic field">
           magnetic fields
          </a>
          ; cf.
          <a href="#CITEREFAshtekar1986">
           Ashtekar 1986
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#CITEREFAshtekar1987">
           Ashtekar 1987
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-191">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-191">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          For a review, see
          <a href="#CITEREFThiemann2006">
           Thiemann 2006
          </a>
          ; more extensive accounts can be found in
          <a href="#CITEREFRovelli1998">
           Rovelli 1998
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#CITEREFAshtekarLewandowski2004">
           Ashtekar &amp; Lewandowski 2004
          </a>
          as well as in the lecture notes
          <a href="#CITEREFThiemann2003">
           Thiemann 2003
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-192">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-192">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFIsham1994">
           Isham 1994
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#CITEREFSorkin1997">
           Sorkin 1997
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-193">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-193">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFLoll1998">
           Loll 1998
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-194">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-194">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFSorkin2005">
           Sorkin 2005
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-195">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">

          </a>
          , ch. 33 and refs therein
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-196">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">

        <li id="cite_note-197">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">

            ^
           </a>

         </span>

          <a href="#CITEREFSchwarz2007">

         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-198">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-198">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>

          , pp. 52–59, 98–122;
          <a href="#CITEREFPenrose2004">

          </a>
          , sec. 34.1, ch. 30
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-199">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-199">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          section
          <a href="/wiki/General_relativity#Quantum_gravity" title="General relativity">
           Quantum gravity
          </a>
          , above
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-200">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">

         </span>

          <a href="/wiki/General_relativity#Cosmology" title="General relativity">
           Cosmology
          </a>
          , above
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-201">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-201">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="#CITEREFFriedrich2005">
           Friedrich 2005
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-202">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-202">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          A review of the various problems and the techniques being developed to overcome them, see
          <a href="#CITEREFLehner2002">
           Lehner 2002
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-203">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-203">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          See
          <a href="#CITEREFBartusiak2000">
           Bartusiak 2000
          </a>
          for an account up to that year; up-to-date news can be found on the websites of major detector collaborations such as
          <a class="external text" href="http://geo600.aei.mpg.de/" rel="nofollow">
           GEO 600
          </a>
          <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070218123705/http://geo600.aei.mpg.de/" rel="nofollow">
           Archived
          </a>
          2007-02-18 at the
          <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">
           Wayback Machine
          </a>
          . and
          <a class="external text" href="http://www.ligo.caltech.edu/" rel="nofollow">
           LIGO
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-204">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-204">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          For the most recent papers on gravitational wave polarizations of inspiralling compact binaries, see
          <a href="#CITEREFBlanchetFayeIyerSinha2008">
           Blanchet et al. 2008
          </a>
          , and
          <a href="#CITEREFArunBlanchetIyerQusailah2007">
           Arun et al. 2007
          </a>
          ; for a review of work on compact binaries, see
          <a href="#CITEREFBlanchet2006">
           Blanchet 2006
          </a>
          and
          <a href="#CITEREFFutamaseItoh2006">
           Futamase &amp; Itoh 2006
          </a>
          ; for a general review of experimental tests of general relativity, see
          <a href="#CITEREFWill2006">
           Will 2006
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-205">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-205">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">

          <a class="external text" href="http://relativity.livingreviews.org/" rel="nofollow">
           Living Reviews in Relativity
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>

        <li>
         <cite class="citation" id="CITEREFAlpherHerman1948">
          <a href="/wiki/Ralph_Asher_Alpher" title="Ralph Asher Alpher">
           Alpher, R. A.
          </a>
          ; Herman, R. C. (1948), "Evolution of the universe",
          <i>
           Nature
          </i>
          ,
          <b>
           162
          </b>
          (4124): 774–775,
          <a href="/wiki/Bibcode" title="Bibcode">
           Bibcode
          </a>
          :
          <a class="external text" href="http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1948Natur.162..774A" rel="nofollow">
           1948Natur.162..774A
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="/wiki/Digital_object_identifier" title="Digital object identifier">
           doi
          </a>
          :
          <a class="external text" href="//doi.org/10.1038%2F162774b0" rel="nofollow">
           10.1038/162774b0
          </a>
         </cite>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Nature&amp;rft.atitle=Evolution+of+the+universe&amp;rft.volume=162&amp;rft.issue=4124&amp;rft.pages=774-775&amp;rft.date=1948&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1038%2F162774b0&amp;rft_id=info%3Abibcode%2F1948Natur.162..774A&amp;rft.aulast=Alpher&amp;rft.aufirst=R.+A.&amp;rft.au=Herman%2C+R.+C.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AGeneral+relativity">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li>
         <cite class="citation" id="CITEREFAndersonCampbellJurgensLau1992">
          Anderson, J. D.; Campbell, J. K.; Jurgens, R. F.; Lau, E. L. (1992), "Recent developments in solar-system tests of general relativity", in Sato, H.; Nakamura, T.,
          <i>
           Proceedings of the Sixth Marcel Großmann Meeting on General Relativity
          </i>
          , World Scientific, pp. 353–355,
          <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
           ISBN

         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Phys.+Rev.&amp;rft.atitle=Generalized+Second+Law+of+Thermodynamics+in+Black-Hole+Physics&amp;rft.volume=D9&amp;rft.issue=12&amp;rft.pages=3292-3300&amp;rft.date=1974&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1103%2FPhysRevD.9.3292&amp;rft_id=info%3Abibcode%2F1974PhRvD...9.3292B&amp;rft.aulast=Bekenstein&amp;rft.aufirst=Jacob+D.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AGeneral+relativity">

         <i>

         </i>
         , Chicago: University of Chicago Press,
         <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
          ISBN
         </a>
         <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-226-87029-4" title="Special:BookSources/0-226-87029-4">
          0-226-87029-4
         </a>
        </cite>
        <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Space%2C+Time%2C+and+Gravity%3A+the+Theory+of+the+Big+Bang+and+Black+Holes&amp;rft.place=Chicago&amp;rft.pub=University+of+Chicago+Press&amp;rft.date=1992&amp;rft.isbn=0-226-87029-4&amp;rft.au=Wald%2C+Robert+M.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AGeneral+relativity">
         <span style="display:none;">
         </span>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <cite class="citation" id="CITEREFWheelerFord1998">

         </a>
         ; Ford, Kenneth (1998),
         <i>
          Geons, Black Holes, &amp; Quantum Foam: a life in physics

         , New York: W. W. Norton,
         <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">

        </span>

         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>

      <ul>
       <li>
        <a class="external text" href="http://www.einstein-online.info/" rel="nofollow">
         Einstein Online
        </a>
        – Articles on a variety of aspects of relativistic physics for a general audience; hosted by the
        <a href="/wiki/Max_Planck_Institute_for_Gravitational_Physics" title="Max Planck Institute for Gravitational Physics">
         Max Planck Institute for Gravitational Physics
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="external text" href="http://archive.ncsa.illinois.edu/Cyberia/NumRel/NumRelHome.html" rel="nofollow">
         NCSA Spacetime Wrinkles
        </a>
        – produced by the numerical relativity group at the
        <a href="/wiki/National_Center_for_Supercomputing_Applications" title="National Center for Supercomputing Applications">
         NCSA
        </a>
        , with an elementary introduction to general relativity
       </li>
      </ul>

                <a href="/wiki/Gibbons%E2%80%93Hawking%E2%80%93York_boundary_term" title="Gibbons–Hawking–York boundary term">
                 Gibbons–Hawking–York boundary term
                </a>
               </li>
              </ul>
             </div>
            </td>
           </tr>
          </table>
         </td>
        </tr>

          </a>

         <td class="navbox-list navbox-even hlist" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px">

             <a href="/wiki/%C3%9Cber_die_von_der_molekularkinetischen_Theorie_der_W%C3%A4rme_geforderte_Bewegung_von_in_ruhenden_Fl%C3%BCssigkeiten_suspendierten_Teilchen" title="Über die von der molekularkinetischen Theorie der Wärme geforderte Bewegung von in ruhenden Flüssigkeiten suspendierten Teilchen">
              Investigations on the Theory of Brownian Movement
             </a>
             " (1905)
            </li>

              <a href="/wiki/Relativity:_The_Special_and_the_General_Theory" title="Relativity: The Special and the General Theory">
               Relativity: The Special and the General Theory
              </a>
             </i>

              </a>
             </i>

             </a>

              Russell–Einstein Manifesto
             </a>

       <li class="interlanguage-link interwiki-zh-classical">
        <a class="interlanguage-link-target" href="https://zh-classical.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E5%BB%A3%E7%BE%A9%E7%9B%B8%E5%B0%8D%E8%AB%96" hreflang="zh-classical" lang="zh-classical" title="廣義相對論 – Classical Chinese">
         文言
        </a>
       </li>
       <li class="interlanguage-link interwiki-war">
        <a class="interlanguage-link-target" href="https://war.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kasahiran_nga_relatibidad" hreflang="war" lang="war" title="Kasahiran nga relatibidad – Waray">
         Winaray
        </a>
       </li>
       <li class="interlanguage-link interwiki-yi">
        <a class="interlanguage-link-target" href="https://yi.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D7%90%D7%9C%D7%92%D7%A2%D7%9E%D7%99%D7%99%D7%A0%D7%A2_%D7%98%D7%A2%D7%90%D7%A8%D7%99%D7%A2_%D7%A4%D7%95%D7%9F_%D7%A8%D7%A2%D7%9C%D7%90%D7%98%D7%99%D7%95%D7%95%D7%99%D7%98%D7%A2%D7%98" hreflang="yi" lang="yi" title="אלגעמיינע טעאריע פון רעלאטיוויטעט – Yiddish">
         ייִדיש
        </a>
       </li>
       <li class="interlanguage-link interwiki-zh-yue">
        <a class="interlanguage-link-target" href="https://zh-yue.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E5%BB%A3%E7%BE%A9%E7%9B%B8%E5%B0%8D%E8%AB%96" hreflang="zh-yue" lang="zh-yue" title="廣義相對論 – Cantonese">
         粵語
        </a>
       </li>
       <li class="interlanguage-link interwiki-zh badge-Q17437798 badge-goodarticle" title="good article">
        <a class="interlanguage-link-target" href="https://zh.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E5%BB%A3%E7%BE%A9%E7%9B%B8%E5%B0%8D%E8%AB%96" hreflang="zh" lang="zh" title="廣義相對論 – Chinese">
         中文
        </a>
       </li>
      </ul>
